13	Pet corner	Dog agility or Saluki / Greyhound running tracks	Fidgety	652	10	Bottom of garden with fairies	12.09.2016
I do the opposite of free feeding
column3: I decided when and how much. But nonetheless the dogs do not get meals in a bowl
column4: they eat throughout the day.

column1: Every piece of kibble is a reward.
Each morning the dog's ration for the day is measured out and goes into my training treat bag. A pocket will do if you don't want to go for the 'doggie bag lady' look.
Then as we go about our day
column3: inside and out
column4: as well as on our walks and during our play and quiet times together - because every single interaction with you is a training event - the dog is rewared with a piece of kibble every time he does what I ask.

column1: This form of feeding works well for us as:
1. The dogs learn quickly that I am the source of good things. This builds that oh-so-important bond
2. The more they do as I ask
column2: the more good things come their way. Paying attention to mum = good things happen. Light bulb moment!

column1: 3. A young pup has a lot o' learnin' to do. Rewarding the small steps towards the larger goal (in training speak
column2: shaping) repeated the umpteen thousand times necessary for a puppy to cotton on to the concept
column3: means lots of little rewards. A puppy would soon balloon into a beach ball if she got both meals and training rewards. So why not dispense with the bowl altogether and make all food a reward?

column1: 4. I know exactly how much as been eaten
column2: I am in control of portions and timing. But as we eat small amounts throughout the day I have minimized the risk of gobbling that might lead to bloat*. Because I am in control of when my dog eats I time eating and exercise accordingly. (With free feeding you might miss that your pup has just eaten as he takes off for high speed Zoomies around the garden.)

column1: This has worked well for mine over the years
column2: balancing the amount of food given while keeping training motivation high via rewards.

column1: * Be aware that there are other causes of bloat as well. Owners of deep chested dogs are most likely to be affected. But bloat can happen to any dog of any size or breed
column2: all dog owners should be aware of the condition
column3: symptoms
column4: and prevention.

column1: ETA:
There are many different ways to approach feeding
column2: not really advocating one over another. (Other than feed nutritionally sound food
column3: in appropriate amounts
column4: keep your dog a healthy weight.) One should choose an approach that is right for the individual dog
column5: but above all
column6: as with every thing one does with one's dog
column7: one should understand  one is doing what one is doing
column8: understand the positives and negatives
column9: and make informed choices.

column3: 14:25	"    Just to emphasize:

column1: Although the federal SKN will no longer be required
column2: please keep abreast of changes to cantonal dog law. Now that the federal government has said it no longer has any interest in promoting canine education abd safety
column3: there seems to be much talk of the various cantons putting stronger measures into place.

column1: We tended to emphasize the federal law in discussions here on EF as that was one constant - but now we need to keep cantonal law in the forefront.
And if I could add a plea:
I would urge all dog owners to keep taking classes voluntarily - especially foreigners
column2: both long term residents and newcomers to Switzerland.  I fear that having abandoned the SKN
column3: the next serious incident involving a dog will result in more draconian measures - and you know if a foreigner is involved it will be worse for us all.

column1: As outsiders to Swiss culture
column2: many of us are taken by surprise by 'Swiss canine norms'. Expectations are indeed different here
column3: not knowing or following those norms will hurt your dog. Fines for allowing your dog to piddle on common grassy areas
column4: barking at noon
column5: restrictions on leaving your dog alone in your flat
column6: to name a few differences - and of course there is a difference in the level of training expected.

column1: Once you settle in
column2: please take a dog class if only to learn what your neighbors will expect of you. Starting on the right foot (and paw) will make it much easier on you and your dog.

column1: There are many good Hundeschule and many different types of classes offered
column2: from basic training to Familienhund to a wide variety of dog sports to special interest courses.  Classes are offered in many different languages
column3: use this hobby as a way to augment your German/French/Italian classes. Or if you prefer
column4: take classes in English -  for instance
column5: EF member Cherrry Tree offers these.

column1: I am saddened that the SKN is no longer required
column2: and having lived through the witch hunt that followed the Oberglatt tragedy
column3: I fear that backsliding on the part of Swiss dog owners will see those dark days return.

column1: Not to mention - taking classes is IME the easiest way to find your feet and make friends in your new home. A good Hundeschule can be a 'soft landing' for newcomers to Switzerland.

column1: Having insects delivered within CH seems ludicrously expensive (I just checked LiB's first link
column2: above â€” grasshoppers there are slightly more expensive than at Qualipet and they charge an additional CHF 9.80 for delivery

column1: Breeding your own insects is not going to work. You won't be able to load them nutritionally

column1: In conclusion

column4: I can usually tempt my dragons to eat not-too-long-dead grasshoppers) â€” and get their customer loyalty card for some extra savings.

113	Pet corner	Yet another smuggling case	meloncollie	584	0	SZ	13.07.2016
From the 20Minuten:
and
A woman in Schaffhausen was found to have made at least 15 trips to smuggle around 50 puppies in
column2: crossing at various Swiss borders. The puppies were mostly Chihuahuas and Prager Rattlers.

column1: Apparently she was selling the dogs online. And apparently
column2: a good number of naive folks were taken in.

column1: I know I sound like a broken record warning puppy buyers of the rampant battery farming and illegal puppy trafficking that goes on in Switzerland - yet people keep falling for this evil activity.
So once more with feeling:
Only buy from a responsible
column3: after having done due diligence on the breeder.

column1: A responsible ethical breeder is one who requires you to undergo an assessment as to your suitability to take on a dog
column2: one who requires you to meet him/her several times - and one who invites you to his/her place to meet the dogs
column3: opens up health records and is happy to discuss health issues referring you to the vet as well
column4: encourages you to see the socialization program in action
column5: and   all your questions and due diligence efforts.

column1: The same goes for those looking to adopt from a rescue
column2: as sadly the battery farmers and puppy traffickers now pose as rescuers.

column1: Again
column2: do your due diligence on the rescue
column3: look for the same things as you would in a breeder  and check the  if applicable. Above all
column4: do not fall for a sob story
column5: as this is what the puppy traffickers play on.  They themselves cause the misery that they use to 'hook' naive would-be adopters in - and responding to that only perpetuates the cycle of abuse.

column1: Be aware that if a dog is brought into Switzerland illegally it can be seized. And if not vaccinated it can be
column2: and in many sad cases has been
column3: ordered euthanized.

column1: So..... Augen Auf Beim Hundekauf. And eyes open when adopting

column2: resp. surgically removed - some questions	guest	722	5	null	1.1.0001

column1: I'm sorry to hear that Lizzie has hurt herself.
I usually try to do anything to avoid the Cone Of Shame
column2: but there are times when there really isn't an alternative.

column1: Recently the Belltie needed a catheter kept in so I could give him meds
column2: and Hooligan had to have a drain left in after surgery. Neither was too impressed
column3: to say the least. It's a full time job keeping them from chewing
column4: isn't it?

column1: My general practice with leg or paw wounds:
While inside
column2: a cotton child's sock loosely put on over the paw
column3: best if you have one with those anti-slip thingies on the sole. Velcro around the ankle
column4: and if long enough around the upper bit of the sock as well. This generally is only enough to stop them chewing while under your supervision
column5: but at least that's something.

column1: When you go outside
column2: wrap the paw loosely in gauze and then cover with VetWrap
column3: the self-adhesive stuff. Take off when you get inside
column4: as the VetWrap
column5: while not fully water tight
column6: would still prevent necessary air from circulating and hinder healing.

column1: So while you are supervising:
More interactive dog play than usual
column2: the idea is that games will distract the dog from wanting to nibble at his paw. A game of search
column3: rounds of (gentle!) fetch
column4: a puzzle game
column5: or simply time on your lap or by your side - anything your dog likes to do with you. A filled kong
column6: or challenging treat ball can be a good distractor when you can't supervise.

column1: I've successfully used distraction/redirection with Hooligan against chewing. (Standard interrupt
column2: then click-and treat for acceptable behavior offered. In this case
column3: she is rewarded for choosing to chew a toy instead of the wound. The goal is that she learns that on chew impulse she should pick up a squeeky toy instead.) But she was already highly trained and responds very well to this protocol; I've not had the same success with the Belltie or with Heffalump. (Well
column4: no success at all with Heffalump yet. He is still very much a work in progress.)

column1: But if Lizzie already responds to distraction and redirection

Mine can't get out of Sabro shoes... but that is because they are form fitting. Which I would think would hinder the healing process. Most of the hard-to-pull-off shoes would be too close fitting for a paw wound

At night the patient always sleeps in my bed so that I can feel if he/she starts chewing at the wound and can stop it immediately. That's the only way I've found to monitor nightime activity that gives me a chance at sleeping too.
But if distraction doesn't work and she is worrying the paw to the point of re-injuring herself... I'm afraid the Cone Of Shame it might have to be.
If management is getting to be a real problem
column2: see the vet sooner rather than later if only for a check. He might decide that healing is going along well enough to give you the OK to relax your routine - and at least then you'd have peace of mind.

column1: Thumbs pressed for Lizzy's recovery.

column3: 18:57	"    As already correctly mentioned
column4: the law in Europe only states that the transported animal must not hinder nor distract the driver. If the animal is tied to the seat
column5: it is transported legally. When using a box
column6: the animal must have enough room to move inside the box.

column1: Both the testers (Swiss TCS
column2: German ADAC) considered the retraining aspect of transporting the animal. Both tests were acceptable for testing the construction of the boxes
column3: and safety of the humans.

column1: But only the ADAC German tests were more relevant to the animal safety.
ADAC reported (As I mentioned above
column2: and for which I received a groan) that in a box the animal will suffer a 25 g force in a 50 Km crash
column3: and will be seriously injured
column4: however the driver will escape injury.

column1: They tested small plastic boxes placed on the back seat
column3: and as the video shows
column4: the animal burst out of the box and hits the back of the front car seat
column5: and would be seriously injured.

column1: They tested a harness secured to the car seat belt. The idea was OK
column2: but in practise there was too much slack in the animal belt to be effective. If the animal belt was made tighter the animal belt remained inadequate and stretched.

column1: They made the tests by using soft toys and & filling them with ballast to achieve animal weights of 5kg for cats and 15Kg for dogs. They didn't have any crash sensors to fit on the dummies
column2: as are used when testing human dummies
column3: but the results showed that in all cases the animals would have serious injuries or be killed.

column1: The ADAC writes
column2: that the law states the animal must have enough room to move. The laws of physics state the animal will be seriously injured in a crash.

column1: Conclusion
column2: there is no completely safe method of transporting animals in cars.

column1: One thing you will learn about this Land Of Many Rules is that enforcement of the rules is often selective and left to the interpretation and attitude of the individual bureaucrat. You can never rely on someone else's experience as a guideline
column2: and you often cannot even rely on the text of the law either.

column1: Now
column2: my advice to newcomers is always the same: whether or not you are required to take the SKN courses
column3: please take it anyway. The SKN courses benefit you and your dog as you learn the peculiarities of the 'Swiss way'.

column1: The two courses are very easy
column2: only two sessions for the Theory and 4-5 sessions for the Practical. The practical course is simply an overview of the basics
column3: an experienced owner will have no trouble whatsoever with it. The courses are inexpensive
column4: usually less than Chf200 each. And there is no test
column5: all you are expected to do is show up and participate in good faith.

column1: IMO
column2: the Theory session explaining dog law in your canton and community is extremely valuable to newcomers
column3: this is info you need and might not come across elsewhere.

column3: 10:35	"    Luapm
column4: I am happy to hear that your dog is very tolerant of your children's behavior. She sounds exceptionally good natured. But I do want to emphasize the 'exceptional' bit.

column1: However
column2: wearing my rescue hat I'd like to share a cautionary tale for all reading:

column1: In the twenty plus years I have been volunteering with rescues I have had many phone calls from vets who have a dog on the table being prepped to be killed for having snapped at a child.  The comment from the owners is always the same:
But we've always let Johnny push
column3: sit on him - and he never objected before!""

column1: Young children should never be allowed to pull
column3: sit on
column4: or do anything to a dog that could cause pain. Dogs are animals
column5: not robots - and they all have a pain threshold. A dog who seems very tolerant of rough handling might one day be pushed beyond his personal threshold... and snap.

column1: Too many dogs are killed because owners put them in situations they cannot - and should not have to - handle. Maybe not today or tomorrow
column2: but one day the dog might be pushed beyond what he can endure.  Again
column3: he is a dog
column4: not a robot.

column1: Sometimes the vet is able to talk the owner into relinquishing the dog to a rescue (hence why I get those calls) but most of the time the dog must die - consequence of the owner's lack of setting boundaries for the children.
An unfair and wholly preventable death. And wholly the owner's fault.
So... while I am happy for you that you have an exceptionally tolerant good natured dog
column2: I could not let your post pass uncommented upon for the sake of others reading it.  And for the sake of all the dogs who didn't get a second chance. I'll say it again (and again and again until the message is loud and clear): no dog should be put into a position where a child is allowed to cause him pain. It is unfair to the dog and unfair to the child.

column1: So for all out there: In bringing a dog into the family with young children you have double the training to do - train your dog
column2: and train your children how to interact safely with your dog.  And of course
column3: supervise interactions when the children are too young to understand your rules.

column1: Thus endeth the sermon.

column1: 192	Pet corner	Federal Dog Control Legislation	meloncollie	68

Many of the provisions in the proposed law are common sense - and things most responsible dog owners already follow. The provision to promote dog safety/handling education among the public is very positive.
But I am concerned that the notion that dogs are inherently good or bad
column2: and that a 'good' dog must be able to tolerate any stressful situation is widepread here; I have seen a tendency here in Switzerland to expect more of dogs than we do of humans. I fear many dogs will be unnessarily condemned under this law.

column1: I would welcome a test of my abilities as a dog owner - whether I am able to correctly assess my dog
column3: to provide an happy life for him that does not infringe on the rights or safely of others. But I worry that the practical test mentioned in the draft would be a test    along the lines of the   (character test) used widely in Germany as was suggested in the press last spring.

column1: A few Swiss trainers - who seem to have the politicians' ear
column2: if the newspapers can be believed - advocate a test which puts a dog in a variety of stressful situations and judges his/her reaction. A dog showing aggression when put under stress - even fear aggression - fails the test.

column1: I have some experience rehabilitating dogs who been badly abused. Many come out of their shells
column2: and could sail through such a test. Some could not - this  t mean that these dogs are dangerous. It simply means that an owner must understand the dog's special needs
column3: and structure his environment accordingly.

column1: (And yes
column2: there are many numpty owners out there who can't or won't recognize this
column3: and should not be in charge of such a dog. But most dogs deserve a chance to live peacefully in the right environment.)

column1: My first collie is a perfect example. Thanks to horrific abuse in his early years he was very fear aggressive.  I worked with him for nine years to overcome his past
column3: he became a wonderful pet.  Even so
column4: to the day he died there were many stresses he simply could not handle - my job was to make sure that he was never put in those situations.

column1: My sweet old boy would not have been able to pass a
column2: and might have been order euthanized under this law. As would several of the foster dogs I've taken on since then. (All of whom have found good
column3: responsible homes...)  I can only hope that we'll see some common sense in the application of this law. Test the owner
column4: test the handling
column5: not just the dog's 'character'.

column1: During the heat of the anti dog hysteria last winter and spring many dog were dumped; pressure from neighbors and landlords was a reason often given. Shelters are full to bursting; the homeless situation here is critical.  I fear it's only going to get worse.

column2: just so you understand what the SKN is
column3: and what you would have to do if you were to work as a (paid) dog carer:

column1: There are two courses
The Theory course is required of all first time dog owners. 'First time dog owner'  usually means not having had a dog registered in your own name in the federal database

Foreigners who have owned a dog in their own name in other countries but not in Switzerland need to contact their cantonal VeterinÃ¤ramt with proof of prior ownership for a ruling on whether they are excused from the theory course
column3: some are not - the decision seems to be individual.

column1: The SKN Practical course is required of all dog owners with every dog acquired after 1 Sept 2008. Owners of multiple dogs will take the course multiple times.
A commercial dog carer - that is
column2: one who is paid - must at a minimum take the same courses as an owner is required to take.

column1: If one is not paid
column2: if one is doing volunteer work
column3: as the previous posts have pointed out one is not required under the law to take the courses. (But individual rescue policies vary
column4: some do ask that you do them.)

column1: But IMO (and IME) it would be a good idea to take the courses even if not required if one wishes to regularly work with dogs
column2: or if one is a newcomer to Switzerland - especially the theory course which discusses dog law and ownership responsibility.  As the examples in Clarasmum's and EastEnder's posts point out
column3: dog law
column4: dog etiquette
column5: and expectations of owners here might be rather different from what you know in your own country.

Perhaps the best article on the SKN classes I have found is by Hundeherz

column1: It is often said that Switzerland is a land of rule makers
column2: not rule followers. A good number of Swiss I know truly believe that many rules here are largely symbolic
column3: and only those with which they are in agreement apply to them.

column1: You also see this at official levels. How the authorities charged with implementing a law interpret it
column2: how (or even if) they choose to enforce it may vary widely. What is strictly enforced in village A might be ignored in village B.

column1: This applies to most rules and regs
The federal SKN requirement is one such example. There are no penalties for non-compliance written into the law
column2: compliance is left to the honor system.

column1: Hence many ignore it
Some Gemeinden have started to check up on dog owners
column3: as it became apparent that there is less honor left in the system than one might wish to believe.

274	Pet corner	Keeping a pet in Switzerland	Spidermann	1
Now that we know which canton and breed/size we can point you to the appropriate information.
The reason this information is necessary is that not only are there the 26 different cantonal laws
column2: but also in some cantons requirements for some breeds/sizes supersede the federal. But this is not the case in Luzern. So...

column1: First you will have to follow federal law
Importation is a federal issue; what you need to do to import your dog is covered in Carl's post - but an even more user friendly site is the BLV's interactive tool
One issue is that docked and cropped dogs are banned in Switzerland. Since Danes are among the breeds frequently docked or cropped
column3: there are two exceptions to the ban on importing docked or cropped dogs:

column1: If a long-term docked/cropped family pet moves   to Switzerland. The underlined bit is critical. Once you are registered in Switzerland you cannot then later import a docked/cropped pet. So if your dog is docked/cropped in your case
column2: assuming you are registered but your wife is not yet
column3: the dog must move with her
column4: on her first entrance to Switzerland with the intention to settle.

column1: The second exception is for a medically necessary amputation; in order to import a docked or cropped dog in this case medical proof needs to be furnished.
There is paperwork to be filled out to import under these exceptions. If your Dane is docked/cropped
column2: the appropriate forms can be found on the BLV website.

column1: Now you have crossed the border you need to:
Register with ANIS
column2: the federal database of all dogs and owners within Switzerland
column3: within 10 days of arrival. You will need a vet to do the registration
column4: so make an appointment ASAP.

column1: Register with your Gemeinde. The form of registration varies from place to place
column2: so contact Einwohnerkontrolle in the first instance. You might need to pay the annual dog tax at this time
column3: or a bill might be sent later.

column1: As you will not have had a dog registered in your name in ANIS
column2: the next question is whether or not you fall under the 'First time owner' requirements to take the federal SKN   course. For foreigners who move to Switzerland with a dog in tow
column3: this is decided on an individual basis. You need to contact the Luzern VeterinÃ¤ramt for a ruling. They can be contacted here:

column1: If you are not excused from the federal SKN Theory course you will need to take it as soon as possible. I always recommend newcomers to Switzerland take the Theory course even when excused
column2: as there is so much one needs to know here - and much of that might be quite different from what you have experienced as a dog owner back home.

column1: In any case you must take the federal SKN   course within 12 months of arrival. The database of certified SKN trainers can be found here
column2: simply contact one in your area and get registered for the course.

column1: Do you speak German well enough to take the course? If not
column2: post a thread here asking for English speaking trainers in your region.

column1: Now - those are the federal issues in a nutshell.
The next set of regulations is at the cantonal level. For Luzern
column2: see the summary from Tier Im Recht
column3: here:

column1: A rough translation of the essentials:
- A dog owner must ensure that your dog  does not pose a danger to the public. A dog owner must ensure that your dog does not sully  streets
column3: sidewalks
column4: park areas
column5: other people's gardens
column6: or agricultural fields. (In other words - you are required to pick up after your dog
column7: and you should not allow him to urinate or mark in these areas.)

column1: - Dog owners or those who take charge of a dog for more than 3 months must register with ANIS within 10 days.

column2: I thought I'd share my experience from February 2015. It was actually much easier than I expected; I was definitely over prepared. Best part = No quarantine! For paperwork
column3: all you need is a Euro Microchip
column4: new rabies shot
column5: APHIS form
column6: and EU health certificate.

column1: DETAILS
Dog: 6.5 year old female boxer dog with docked tail (rescued when she was 1yr)
Weight: 50 pounds
Airline: American Airlines
Kennel: n/a (Rode as Emotional Support Animal in cabin)
Time: Arrived at the airport 3-4 hours before scheduled flight
Departure info: February 25th
Price: None
Route: Dallas DFW --> New York JFK (had a dog potty area) --> Zurich ZRH
RABIES & MICROCHIP INFO
- We opted to insert a Euro Microchip instead of buying a reading device
column2: so our dog had to get a new rabies shot. You can do the rabies shot right after implantation of the microchip the same day if you want; the rabies shot just has to be after the implantation.

column1: - Additional Notes:
(1) The microchip our vet used was petlink.net (it met the ISO Standards 11784/11785) and the cost was $50USD
(2) We had the vet hand sign a couple vaccination records in blue ink
column2: since they normally tended to use stamps for signatures.

column1: (3) The vet charged $15USD for the rabies shot.
(4) She got her microchip and rabies shot on Jan 12
EU CERTIFICATE INFO

- The most important note about the EU Certificate is that it must be issued within 10 days of travel (including the time to be mailed to and returned from the USDA office to be officially stamped) and it must be completed by a USDA Accredited Veterinarian.
- Additional Notes:
(1) The vet charged $60USD for the visit and completing the form.
(2) As a precautionary measure
column2: we had this vet fill out an APHIS Form 7001 for traveling on the plane.

column1: (3) All forms completed in blue ink.

(4) We mailed the completed EU Health Certificate and APHIS FORM 7001 by the accredited USDA vet and a signed rabies vaccination certificate from our normal vet to the export department at the USDA Animal and Plant Health Inspection Services (for us in Austin). There is was officially stamped and mailed back in a pre-paid envelope we had originally sent. It cost $38USD plus shipping to and back. You will have to use 1-3days shipping via Fedex/UPS to ensure you get everything done within the 10 days of travel.
(5) Here is the link for the new EU health certificate.
EMOTIONAL SUPPORT ANIMAL INFO
If this qualifies
column3: you have to call American Airlines and submit an ESA Authorization Form (completed by a Mental Health Professional). My dog sat and slept right by my legs and partially under the seat in front of me.

column1: DOCKED TAIL INFO
A dog with a docked tail is allowed (as relocation goods) if the following conditions are met:
1) It must be imported by the owner itself
2) It has been owned for at least six months before moving to Switzerland
3) The dog has a Microchip (ISO Standard 11784
column2: which only contains digits as identification code)
column3: valid rabies vaccination
column4: and a Veterinary certificate

column5: the vet vaccination certificate

column2: Longbyt has touched on an important point: cantonal dog law
column3: and how you will be affected.

column1: Be aware that dog control functions at three levels in Switzerland: federal
column3: and community.

column1: At the federal level
column2: animal welfare issues are addressed. These include the federal SKN classes. Control is largely addressed at the cantonal and community level
column3: these include breed bans
column4: leash laws
column5: picking up
column6: fines for infractions - and in some cases additional training beyond the federal requirements.

column1: ZÃ¼rich is an example of the latter. In canton ZH
column2: due to his size (over 15kg or 45cm) a ridgeback is a List 1 dog. This means that you are required to do additional training courses. This applies to all dogs born after 31 Dec 2010; people moving to ZÃ¼rich after that date with a dog born before that date need to contact the cantonal VeterinÃ¤ramt for a decision on your individual case.

column1: The courses are required are puppy training
column3: adult training. Which courses
column4: how many hours
column5: etc. that will be required in your case will depend on the age of your dog.

column1: If you are excused from the cantonal training requirement due to your dog's age
column2: then you will simply need to follow the federal training requirements
column3: the SKN courses.

column1: There are two of these classes
column2: the SKN Theory and SKN Practical.

column1: The Theory class is required of all first time dog owners
column2: to be done before one acquires a dog. The definition of first time owner is clear for all Swiss residents: having had a dog registered the ANIS database
column3: in your own name.

column1: It is less clear for people moving to Switzerland with a dog in tow. Obviously you already have a dog
column2: so are not a first time owner - but you are a first time owner in Switzerland. In this case you need to contact the cantonal VeterinÃ¤ramt for a ruling on whether you are excused from the federal SKN Theory course
column3: or not. Some people have been
column4: some are required to take it. The decision is made on each individual case.

column1: All owners of any dog acquired after 1 Sept 2008 are required to do the SKN Practical course. You have a year to get this done.
If you are required to do the canton ZH List 1 courses
column2: these will take the place of the federal SKN Practical course.

column1: And now for my usual sermon.

Even if excused from the courses - SKN or List 1 - please take them. There is information you need to be a responsible dog owner in Switzerland that you would have a hard time finding elsewhere - and not knowing what is expected of you is how you put a foot (paw) wrong here. You don't want your dog to suffer because of your lack of information. The classes are fun
column2: not expensive. Iin fact the SKN classes are quite cheap
column3: but even the ZH classes don't cost all that much in the relative scheme of things.

column1: More importantly
column2: classes are an opportunity for a 'soft landing' for you. You will likely meet kindred spirits in class
column3: some of whom may become friends. You will have a chance to practice your German
column4: to learn about your community. A good Hundescule is a very valuable resource for a dog owner. Even for those with decades of experience.

column1: I'll make a special plea for your dog and the List 1 classes:

The List 1 requirements (and the banning of 8 breeds) came into effect via a public referendum. The good voters of ZÃ¼rich are wary of large dogs - and the sad fact of breed prejudice is that your ridgeback will prompt more wariness among some members of the public than
column3: a golden retriever - although they are both List 1 dogs. Taking the classes will better equipe you to handle local attitudes towards our larger canine friends.

column1: Do you read German? If so
column2: here is a summary of the ZH cantonal law
column3: from the excellent folks at Tier Im Recht

column1: The text of the actual law is linked at the top. Note that each canton has different dog laws - if you visit another canton you will be expected to know and follow their laws. The Tier Im Recht website is your best friend here - all cantons are summarized.
(Note that the Thai Ridgeback is banned in GE - not the 'regular' Ridgeback.)
The final say in all matters governing dogs in canton ZH is the cantonal VeterinÃ¤ramt. The website
column3: is here:

column1: ZH dog law is detailed here - if you have questions please go to the source
column2: do not rely on unofficial information. Including my post here.

column1: Another thing you should know while searching for dog care:
Unlike in most of our home countries
column3: paid - dog care is regulated in Switzerland. Anyone caring for a dog in return for money must have at a minimum the same training courses as an owner would - that is the federal SKN courses or the cantonal equivalent.  It only makes sense that anyone paid to care for a dog be held to the same standard as an owner is.

column1: The SKN courses allow a carer to care for up to 5 dogs. Caring for more than 5 dogs requires either the FBA or the Tierpfleger diploma
The onus is on you
column3: to ensure that the person you hire to care for your dog is compliant with the law - and the liability falls to you if you hire someone who is not.

column1: Please be aware that there are many folks offering dog care who are not compliant - including most of the people looking for a side job here on EF. No one should flaunt the law
column3: but given that your dog is a List 1 dog
column4: I would in even stronger terms caution you against employing anyone who is not compliant - for your dog's sake.

348	Pet corner	Volunteer dog walking at a refuge?	Vlh22	816	3	UK
Good for you for wanting to help out. Working with homeless dogs is very rewarding work.
Just a word about therapy dogs

An official therapy dog is highly trained - and before that training can begin the dog has been put through an extensive selection program to determine if he/she has the right character for this work. It's a very rigorous program
column2: one only a select few dogs qualify for.

column1: Not all dogs are fit to take on the role of a therapy dog. In fact
column2: it's likely few of those in shelters will be - honestly one cannot expect a shelter dog to take on that role.  Rather the reverse is usually the case - we need to provide therapy for these poor
column3: sometimes damaged
column4: critters.

column1: Please keep this in mind - the goal of volunteering with homeless dogs is to help the dogs
column2: full stop. It's all about their needs
column3: nor ours. The benefit we derive from doing good work
column4: from knowing that we have made a difference
column5: is an 'extra'.

column1: When volunteering be very clear about your level of expertise. It is important
column3: for the safety of others around you
column4: and critically for the dog
column5: that you are matched with a dog whose behavior is within the scope of your expertise. Please don't take this wrong - I honestly do applaud you for wanting to do this - but I must stress that taking charge of a dog whose behavior is beyond your experience would be unfair to the dog
column6: and to all.

column1: Most  shelter staff try to match the walkers and dogs - but don't be afraid to stress your experience level and speak up if you feel you cannot handle any dog you are paired with.

Many of the dogs in shelters ended up there because their owners couldn't provide (or couldn't be a*sed to provide) basic training. A good dog walking program is an extension of a training or rehab program
column2: as you walk the dog you are continually reinforcing the work the shelter's trainers have started.

column1: That said
column2: yes dogs land in shelters who do not have 'ishoos' and who would be a good fit for you. But again
column3: it's important to set realistic expectations with even these 'easy' dogs.

column1: I would counsel separating your interest in dog therapy programs from your interest in helping shelter dogs.
There is some cross-over
column2: as I truly do believe - and experience on a daily basis - the theraputic value of living with dogs. My  dogs are the center of my world
column3: and they are the anchor that keeps me centered.

column1: But I cannot expect my dogs - all adoptees who came with either physical problems or emotional baggage - to provide 'real' therapy to me
column2: as a trained therapy dog would. No
column3: it's my job to do that for them. But in helping them to live happier more fulfilling lives I gain so very
column4: very much. Let's just stay it's a mutually beneficial relationship.

column1: As for the SKN:
The BLV's FAQ still says that one is not required to have the SKN to walk shelter dogs
column2: as it is volunteer work. I have noticed
column3: though
column4: while looking for something else
column5: that a couple of shelters in ZH are now requiring the courses
column6: citing the BLV. I've looked for a policy change and couldn't find any reference. Curious. But until something official appears on the BLV site
column7: I'd go with the status quo - volunteer dog care does not require the SKN as far as compliance with federal law goes. Each shelter is of course free to set it's own policies.

column1: HOWEVER - it's always good to do the courses
column2: for one's own knowledge. Even more so when working with shelter dogs who might not have had the easiest time of it and so need our understanding.

column1: Several shelters offer the SKN course free to their volunteer dog walkers. This would be a win-win for you
Wishing you all the very best. Nothing so uplifting as the company of a dog. And knowing that you are helping that dog begin a new
column3: chapter brings a warm glow that can't be beat.

column1: Good luck!

column2: from ca. CHF 20 per hour to CHF 100 per hour.  Group walking is usually at the lower end

column1: Some dogwalkers will charge mileage on top of that.
Other things you need to know about :

Anyone doing commercial (paid) dog care must have completed certain education courses. It is your responsibility to ascertain that your dog walker has the necessary certificates. (For care of up to 5 dogs
column2: the SKN courses - the same course all owners must take* - are sufficient.) You can read more here:

column1: Make sure you understand insurance liability coverage. Talk to your insurer to understand what falls under your coverage* and/or the walker's. Ask the walker for copies of his/her policy.
Make sure you have a written contract
Get references
* Since you mention that you are new to Switzerland
column2: a couple of points that you might not have come across yet:

column1: You are required to take out liability insurance (Privathaftpflicht) of at least 1 mio.
You are required to take courses yourself. There are two requirements
column2: federal SKN Theory and Practical courses
column3: and the ZH cantonal List 1 courses. (A lab is a List 1 breed.)  Whether you are required to do the more extensive ZH List 1 courses will depend on when your dog was born
column4: before or after 31 Dec 2010.

405	Pet corner	Lepto 6 Vaccine for Dogs	Mrs. Doolittle	2
Bringing this back up
column2: because after discussion with my vet I decided to have Hooligan vaccinated against Lepto this year
column3: using the Lepto 6 vaccine.

column1: As per my earlier post Hooligan has epilepsy which puts her in the 'compromised' category - so we had to stop vaccinating her some years ago.
But that decision shouldn't be static. Each year we review the incidence of the various diseases and weigh the consequences of disease against Hooligan's own 'risk profile' and current health.
Hooligan is still a very active dog who lives and hikes in areas where there have been Lepto cases reported (this year is expected to be particularly bad)
column2: our garden is full of mice (rodent urine is a vector) - and she has been seizure-free for a good long time now (knock wood!).  All in all
column3: this year I felt that the benefit of having her vacc'd against Lepto far outweighs the risk. Lepto is a horrible disease
column4: sadly often fatal.

column1: So just wanted to say to all whose dogs are 'compromised' as Hooligan is - it's a good idea to have regular discussions with your vet
column2: in light of current lepto incidence in your particular area and in light of your dog's individual health factors.

column1: By the way
column2: Hooligan  has shown no signs of adverse reaction.

column1: Young Heffalump gets vaccinated regularly as a matter of course. With the ancient Belltie we do a similar review as to benefits/risks for his individual situation.

hi guys
so i have been busy with importing my cat (fully grown

column1: bear in mind that the cat is flying solo (not with a passenger)
FSVO permit took the longest
column2: but its a very simple process when you know what to do...       For the accompanied entry into Switzerland from a rabies risk country
column3: the animal (dog
column4: cat or ferret) requires the following:     Â·

column1: The microchip must conform to ISO standard 11784 and must be readable with a reader as specified in ISO standard 11785
column3: which contains only numbers and no asterisks (*). Otherwise
column4: you must make sure you carry a suitable reader with you.      Â·

column1: A rabies vaccination can only be recognized as valid if the microchip was implanted before the vaccination. The rabies vaccination is not valid if it is carried out before the animal has reached the age of 12 weeks.      Â·

A blood sample must be taken from the animal no sooner than 30 days after the rabies vaccination (but within the validity period of the vaccination). This sample must undergo analysis for rabies antibodies. This analysis must be carried out in a laboratory approved by the EU. A list of approved laboratories can be found at  http://ec.europa.eu/food/animal/live...pproval_en.htm
The blood analysis is followed by a further waiting period of 3 months until entry into Switzerland is possible
column2: provided the result is at least 0.5 IU/mL.     Â·          Must be issued by the official veterinarian responsible or the authorities responsible in the country of origin. The model veterinary certificate and declaration of ownership can be found via the following link:  http://www.blv.admin.ch/themen/04670...x.html?lang=en      Â·          To enter Switzerland via a Swiss airport
column3: a permit issued by the FSVO is required. To obtain a permit
column4: you must send the following documents to the FSVO before your departure: a copy of the laboratory report on the blood analysis
column5: microchip certificate with date of implantation
column6: certificate of rabies vaccinations and the application form (obtainable at  http://www.blv.admin.ch/themen/04670...x.html?lang=en ). The permit costs CHF40. This fee is collected by customs upon entry.     We draw your attention to the fact that
column7: if the animal does not fly with the owner in the passenger cabin

column5: there are battery farms and scams in every country. The numbers - let alone the sights - will make you ill
column6: then make you cry
column7: then make you very
column8: very angry. No country is immune
column9: no country can sit firmly on it's high horse.

column1: Wealthy Switzerland is a target for foreign puppy mill operators. There are ready buyers with money in their pockets. Illegal imports are a continual problem
column3: some of those battery farmers do come from eastern Europe. And they also come from southern Europe. And western Europe. And the UK. In fact
column4: the only reason that you don't see many illegal puppy farm imports from the rest of the world ending up here is that the cost of shipping eats too far into the profit.

column1: It should be noted
column3: that Swiss hands are far from clean. Show me a foreign battery farmer
column4: and I'll show you a Swiss counterpart brokering the sale and taking a chunk of the profit.

column1: BTW
column2: the only reason you don't see more puppy mills in Switzerland is that the cost of land is so high. You see plenty of BYBs and irresponsible breeding
column3: though.

456	Pet corner	Dog Food Storage Suggestion	guest	656	0	null	1.1.0001
The most useless drawer in my kitchen has now become useful.
I am talking about the drawer fitted with the insert for holding bottles. I never used it and was thinking I could put it to use storing dog food.

We keep the bulky bags (12 - 15kg) downstairs in plastic bins and use smaller tubs (rice keepers from Japan) to transfer the food for daily use. The rice keepers were too big for the bottle drawer and were taking up valuable space in another cupboard.
I looked everywhere and finally found the perfect solution. From Rotho. They have a new line of pet food storage containers.
As we needed 3 bins I bought the 4.5 litre containers.
I could not find these containers in any store so I ordered them online. They were delivered with an invoice.
I sawed off the inside wires of the basket for the bottles so the containers fit inside the frame.
I adjusted the height of the little drawer above and in there keep all the dog meds which are given with the food. The dog food scale is not in the photo but it sits between the containers.

470	Pet corner	What would you pay a dog sitter?	John_H	1
column3: 18:55	"    If the sitter is staying in your house then more time is devoted to your dog. More time will of course cost more.

column1: When a sitter takes a dog into his/her house the dog slots in with the sitter's family and routine. The sitter is doing his/her normal housework
column3: caring for his/her own family and pets in addition to yours. In this situation fewer hours a day are devoted exclusively to your dog.

column1: When the sitter moves into your home obviously the sitter does not do any of the above - the sitter's time is exclusively devoted to your dog.

The CHF 200 per day average is generally figured on an assumed 8 hours spent actually working with your dog at CHF 25 per hour - the same wage you would pay a babysitter or other household worker. But you are getting a bargain - the sitter is there to care for your dog throughout the full day just as you would. Yes
column3: you would have negotiated how much personal time the sitter would have away from the house during that time
column4: and a good deal of the time at your home is spent doing one's own thing around the house - but 200 per day is actually a very good deal.

column1: (I know of one sitter who charges CHF 600 per day - that is
column2: 25 per hour for a 24 hour day.)

column1: But either at your home or the sitter's
column2: while one is not 'working' that is
column3: interacting with your dog the full time
column4: nonetheless the sitter takes on what is in effect 24/7 responsibility
column5: just as the owner would. If a crisis occurs in the middle of the night
column6: one needs a sitter who is both willing and able to respond. That responsibility is actually what you are paying for.

column1: My sitter and I have been through two of the awful 'what if' situations. One anticipated and thus discussed and decision-making planned for
column2: the other completely out of the blue. Every sitter and owner need to anticipate these terrible possibilities - and what you pay your sitter reflects the willingness and ability to take on this responsibility.

column1: It should be stressed
column2: though - if you are paying the sitter then under the TSchV the sitter needs to have done at a minimum both the SKN courses - the same courses that any owner has to do. A sitter takes on owner responsibilities
column3: so it makes sense that the same legalities apply. I know that many people consider themselves as sitting 'casually' rather than professionally but still want to be paid - one needs to understand that it is payment that triggers the education requirements.

column1: It is only the case of sitting as a favor
column3: where the education requirements do not apply.

column1: I've said this before but it bears repeating:
If you find an otherwise promising sitter who has not yet done the SKN courses
column2: why not sponser that person for the course
column3: have him/her do it with your dog while sitting for you? Win-win all around.

column1: 489	Pet corner	pedigree costs - golden retriever	CornishPasty	1

Part of what makes a reputable breeder is the extensive health and genetic testing done on the parent dogs to determine if each is fit to breed and then if the pair is a good match - this will significantly add to the cost of breeding.  From the little I know of the SKG world
column2: in the two breeds I see most often Swiss breed clubs do seem - at least on paper - to take these issues more seriously
column3: with more oversight
column4: than
column5: say
column6: what I have seen in the rescue fall-out from breeders in the US.

column1: (Bearing in mind that this is not my world - I generally only come into contact with breeders via rescue work. But from that perspective
column2: I respect many of the breeders I have met in Switzerland and Germany.)

column1: Add in all the rest of what a good breeder does - necessary accomodation (you can guess how much a property with sufficient land costs in Switzerland)
column3: health testing and care of puppies
column4: etc.
column5: - and you will of course see higher prices.

column1: There is a lot more to rearing healthy puppies of sound temperament than just vaccinating. Look at the retriever.ch site to read up on the various genetic health issues of the breed. A good breeder plans a pairing with genetic health in mind - and the tests involved are expensive.
The reputable breeders I know don't actually make much money from breeding - most cover their costs. Good breeders generally do it out of love for the dogs.
It's the battery farmers
column2: who do none of the necessary health testing
column3: who do no socialization
column4: who toss any two dogs together with no thought for genetics
column5: who breed a dog every season until it drops dead
column6: whose dogs live in misery in small cages their entire lives
column7: whose pups are often ill with parvo
column8: with respiratory infections
column9: with inherited conditions - these are the folks cashing in.

column1: These folks need to be stopped. And the only way to stop them is to educate people to buy only from a reputable breeder.  Stop supporting the barstewards who are ruining our dogs.
Bottom line
column2: though - the purchase price or adoption fee is but a drop in the bucket. Dog ownership is expensive - especially in Switzerland.

525	Pet corner	Maltese puppy search	Orion2104	930	1	Glattfelden	31.12.2014
Orion
There are not that many breeders in Switzerland
column2: and therefore not many puppies. Which is a good thing
column3: for the welfare of the animals.

column1: You see
column2: good breeders do not plan a litter until they have enough interest expressed from potential buyers in order to ensure that there are homes ready for their puppies. Most breeders will have waiting lists
column3: some a year or more in advance.

column1: If one wants a puppy of a certain breed
column2: one needs to first establish a relationship with the breeders.  Generally
column3: you need to contact each breeder
column4: introduce yourself
column5: explain who you are
column6: what kind of home you can offer their pup
column7: etc. If you meet the breeder's criteria you would then meet him/her and the dogs. If the 'interview' is successful - that is
column8: if you have convinced the breeder that you can offer a good forever home to one of his/her pups
column9: you would then be invited to join the waiting list for the next (or a subsequent) litter.

column1: The process of developing a relationship with a breeder is in the best interest of the pups - which is what all good owners want.
It is not often that a breeder has a pup to offer a last minute buyer
column2: but sometimes it happens - for instance when a buyer already on the waiting list drops out.

column1: The reason that we stress the 'proper' way to find one's puppy is that the breeders out there who advertise pups ready immediately are often battery farms/puppy mills. Often these dogs are bred in abusive conditions
column2: no thought to genetic health or suitability
column3: the pups sick
column4: poorly socialized
column5: mentally damaged - and if found in Switzerland often illegally imported. Sadly
column6: small fluffy dogs - including the Maltese - are the breeds most often subjected to this horrific trade. Battery farming of puppies is vile - please do not support these criminals and animal abusers.

column1: Fortunately
column2: the new revision to the EU passport scheme
column3: in force as of 1 Jan 2015
column4: has stricter measures put into place to help combat these barstewards.

column1: So - plan for as long a search as necessary to develop a relationship with a good breeder. A dog will be with you 15+ years - waiting some months or a year is nothing in the long run.
To start your search
column2: look for the breed club of the SKG  - in Switzerland that is the Zwerghundclub:

column1: For more discussion on the process of finding a puppy from a Swiss breeder
And just because rescue is my thing - as a possible alternative
column2: and if you are in a position to offer a rescue dog the right kind of home
column3: from time to time take a gander at the Tierdatenbank
column4: the database of homeless animals here in Switzerland:

column1: While there are currently no Maltesers in need of a home
column2: I have seen some listed on this database
column3: a few recently. Yes
column4: purebred dogs do indeed land in shelters or in search of new homes. It might be worthwhile to also keep an eye on the database as you continue your search.

column1: And of course  - because the ins and outs of the TSchV is also my thing - if you are a first time dog owner in Switzerland
column2: have you done the SKN Theory course
column3: or if not a first time owner but new to Switzerland have you contacted the cantonal VeterinÃ¤ramt for a ruling on whether you must take it or not?

column1: If you fall into the category of those required by federal law to take the course
column2: good breeders will want to see your SKN certificate before inviting you onto the waiting list. If you are required to take it but haven't yet
column3: this might be why your search is stalled. In which case
column4: you'd be well advised to make the course a priority.

column1: Anyway
column2: all the best to you and your future four-footed friend.

column1: There is huge concern at the moment with dogs not being properly imported- due to the possibility of being infected with all sort
column2: and also due to the possibility of them coming from dreadful puppyfarms
column3: with defects
column4: illness and weakness and behavioural problems
column5: lack of socialisation and much too young- due to the way they are kept in the first few weeks of life
column6: to mothers that are forced to produce litter after litter in the most appalling circumstances. Poorly socialised dogs are often scared
column7: and will tend to bite when 'threatened' by noisy and boisterous children- and then abandonned in a shelter!

column1: A long article about this in the current 'Terre et Nature' magazine- with an estimation of of 100s of illegal dogs being bought just this year in Romandie alone- mainly chihuhahas and other small breeds- many who die within days or weeks of being bought. The importing gangs have no conscience- and often use relatives or friends living here as intermediaries- very happy to make 'easy' money.
Vets are being asked to keep a very sharp eye on this- and to report any owner they suspect from illegal import. The article finishes by saying that
column2: even if the buyer buy in good faith- they can still be fined for not doing the necessary checks- picking upa dog from a car-park or at the border- without visiting the breeder and seeing at least the mother with the puppies- to pay a cheaper price. They can still be fined 1000s of francs for importing without due care.

column1: Of course
column2: this does not apply to you- but as I just read the article today
column3: I thought it was a good idea to share.

column1: So
column2: don't panic- it is too late now. But- get your dog properly checked
column3: vaccinated and recorded in passport
column4: and anibis +Gemeinde registered. The last thing any vets wants to do is get an owner- and therefore a dog (it can be quarantined or even euthanazed in case of doubt) - but they will do if they are concerned. Keep a VERY close eye on the vaccination date

column1: 534	Pet corner	New Regulations Against Abusive Breeding Practices	meloncollie	555	0	SZ	10.12.2014
Swiss animal protection law already forbids 'Qualzucht'
column3: but the current definitions are vague. The BLV has now revised the legislation adding definitions and specifically forbidding certain practices. The revision is set to enter into force on 1 Jan 2015.

column1: The provisional text:
And an article by TIR:
I am especially thrilled to see that  the proposal forbids breeding animals where due to the pairing it cannot be ruled out that the offspring would suffer loss of one of the senses
column3: or that due to anatomy the animal would have difficulty in giving birth.

column1: This addresses double merle breeding (collies
column3: aussies
column4: etc.) as well as other breeds  such as danes and dalmations
column5: where known problematic genetic combinations can result in deafness or blindness. It also addresses breeding animals whose heads are so large that cesarean sections rather than natural births have become the norm (some of the bulldogs). The revision also addresses many health issues and extreme conformation problems.

column1: Additionally
column2: the proposal explicitly forbids breeding toy dogs whose expected weight is less than 1500g - the so-called tea-cup trend.

column1: It also forbids breeding cats with shortened forelegs
column2: the so-called kangaroo-cats. The legislation applies to all breeding
column3: not just cats and dogs.

column1: Tables 1 and 2 following the text list specific 'Qualzucht' issues.
TIR is pleased to see these proposals
column2: but one objection they make is that the proposal sets up a control system that would rely on private persons. TIR is concerned that would allow for vested interest groups to water down the enforcement and would like to see control fall under the aegis of the BLV or the cantonal VeterinÃ¤ramt.

column1: But this is a huge step in the right direction.

column1: Theoretically there cannot be a stray in Switzerland as all dogs should be chipped... But the reality is there may still be a few unchipped dogs
column2: or dogs who are chipped but the owner has not updated the contact details. Nonetheless
column3: once you catch the dog first priority should be to have him scanned.

column1: Any vet will scan the dog
column2: this should be free of charge for the finder of a lost animal. If it is after hours and there isn't a 24/7 emergency clinic in the area just call any vet practice
column3: most will have an after-hours cover group.

column1: Around my area police do not have holding kennels
column2: but larger stations should have a scanner
column3: . This is usually my second port of call
column4: I prefer to enlist the help of a vet rather than the police as vets tend to be more sympathetic.

column1: Once scanned
column2: the vet will file a report with ANIS... And if the police do the scanning
column3: I'd recommend calling yourself as well
column4: just to make sure the report got done. (Often stray animals are not a priority for the police) ANIS will contact the owner.

column1: Now to the legalities
column2: once you have caught the dog:

column1: A finder is required to file a report to the cantonal Meldstelle
column2: for all found animals. There are two online reporting sites that will fulfil this obligation:       .

column1: look under 'gefundene Tiere' (can't link on the iPad
Or call the cantonal Meldstelle directly.
Just an FYI
column2: the waiting period before a found animal can be rehomed is 60 days
column3: starting from the date the finder report is filed.

column1: If you wish to keep a found dog at your home during the waiting period you need permission from the cantonal Meldstelle. But be aware that if a finder chooses to keep the dog during this period the expenses in such a case are born by the finder. (If an owner is found you can ask the owner to refund your expenses
column2: but the owner is not obliged to do so.)

column1: If you can't keep a found animal with you
column2: find out from the cantonal Meldstelle who the official cantonal Tierheim is
column3: this is the shelter obliged to take the animal. Other Tierheim might charge you for the animal's care
column4: as they are not obliged to take in strays. (But some are willing to help nonetheless.)

column1: Here's hoping this dog can be caught
column2: and helped back to his owner... Or helped
column3: full stop
column4: if it turns out that the owner doesn't deserve him.

column1: 655	Pet corner	dog walker needed [Zurich]	croberts	1
Not a license per se
column2: but you are correct Lucy. Unlike what most of us are used to in our home countries
column3: commercial (that is
column4: paid) dog care is a regulated activity in Switzerland.

column1: A dog walker will need at a minimum to have done the SKN theory and practical courses. These are the same courses that all dog owners are required to do.
(Have you recently acquired your dog
column3: Croberts? If so
column4: you need to do the course (or courses - this is the short version) yourself. Search for the term 'SKN' there are many threads explaining this requirement.)

column1: It only make sense that someone who is being paid to look after a dog be held to the same training standards as an owner.
The requirement for the SKN courses applies to anyone caring for 5 or fewer dogs at a time. If one is caring for more than that
column3: the FBA or the Tierpfleger diploma
column4: depending on what is offered. If caring for more than 5 dogs
column5: the carer must be registered with the cantonal VeterinÃ¤ramt.

column1: The above does not apply if the carer is not being paid. Friends may still do friends a favor.
It is the responsibility of the owner to ascertain that the dog carer is duly qualifed. Fines have been given out if a complaint is made and it is discovered that the carer is not in compliance.

One should also ensure that a dog carer is duly insured against liability. Generally someone working in your home (which would include walking the dog) is covered under your Privathaftpflicht (in ZH and about half the cantons Privathaftpflicht/Liability insurance is mandatory for dog owners
column2: the cover sum varies by canton)
column3: but one should check with one's insurance provider for the specifics of the policy. A carer who runs his/her own business
column4: though
column5: likely is not covered under your policy and would have to have his own liability insurance.

column1: Hope you find the person you need

column1: The moths apparently all fly at more or less the same time
column2: or at least within a very narrow window. They mate and then lay eggs on fresh box trees and then die within a few hours. They can smell box trees from miles away. So the spread of the moth or even its survival depends very much on what happens on these two or three nights. Heavy rain can prevent them from flying. Atmospheric conditions can prevent the odour of the box reaching them. If the flight of the moths coincides with increased bat activity
column3: they also get decimated (bats love the box moths). So lots of factors can transpire to either decimate or help the next generation of caterpillars.

column1: 763	Pet corner	Need info on taking my dog back to USA	dvincent	916	2	4052 Basel	15.02.2014
Hi I just flew with my dog to the States in Nov (for a long holiday) and back to Zurich in Jan.  She was also in-cabin with me and honestly
column2: no one knew I had her with me the entire time!  <<Bother to the US and back to Switzerland.  I had to keep offering the fact that I had a dog in my bag...  and hey
column3: here dont you want to check my paperwork!

column1: Checking in at the airport.. I showed her EU Pet Passport and a health certification I got from her vet within 10 days of the flight.  They weighed her and the bag to make sure we were under the limit.  And
Walked through security and screening - no one cares about her papers.
Walked onto the plane - no one ever asks about her papers again.  I have boarded a plane three times w her and never once did anyone ask.  But they might not have noticed her in the carrier either.
Going through customs in Washington Dulles - no one asks about her papers.  In fact
column2: I carried her in my arms as customs officials ask how my trip was etc.

column1: It was a similar experience on the way back from USA > Switzerland.  I just had to go to USDA to get extra certification on her health certificate which again no one bothered to ask me for.  I offered the documentation that was so painful to get.  (A three hour drive to the closest APHIS office in Richmond VA and another three hours back home... days before my flight!)
Hope this helps.  Feel free to let me know if you have any other questions.
PS - A great tip is to let a (friendly) flight attendent know you have the pup w you.  I did this on the way home
column2: and the attendent gave me a whole row to myself since there was room!  He and some of the other lady attendents kept asking if the pup was ok.  He even told me if it werent for some of the snotty attendents (hehe his words!) and probably air safetly regulations - he would let me hold her out of the bag.  They helped me to the biggest bathrooms on the plane for me to bring pup in w her potty pads to do her business and stretch.  We had a great experience!

column1: I would recommend that all dog owners regularly train the 'leave' command - and better yet
column2: regularly train your dogs never to eat food from the ground
column3: never to accept food from another person. (Offering adulterated treats is also a favorite poisoning tactic.)

column1: Not an easy thing to do
column2: especially when you have Hoover Hounds like mine. But worth working on.

column1: We often do 'ignore the sausage on the ground' exercises at our Hundeschule
column2: in order to teach the dogs just that.

column1: Put the dog in the heel position or on short lead if necessary
column2: walk by a plate with kibble on it - keep your dog's attention on you
column3: offer an even better treat when he ignores what is on the ground. Repeat a million times
column4: varying your speed
column5: direction
column6: left/right side heel
column7: etc. Next try hiding the kibble in unexpected places as you walk by.  Once your dog can reliably ignore kibble on the ground do the same with a higher value treat
column8: repeat. Continue in the same vein until what is on the ground is super high value (like a sausage).

column1: Do this on your own along your favorite walking trails and in your garden. The more you reinforce the fact that things on the ground must be left alone and that food only comes from you
column2: the safer your dog will be.

826	Pet corner	Changes to the TSchV
column2: in force as of 1 Jan 2014	meloncollie	1

column1: Several articles of the TSchV (and related legislation) have been revised - these changes are set to go into effect on 1 Jan 2014.
The text of the revised law is here:
The changes are explained here:
Click on 'Revision Tierschutzverordnung: Die wichtigsten Ã„nderungen fÃ¼r Heimtierhaltende'
To give a very rough translation of bits that affect most of us in the summary linked above: (And those whose German is better than mine
column2: please correct me where I have made mistakes.)

column1: Keeping dogs in kennels (Art. 70 Abs. 2 / Art. 72)
Dogs do not have to be kenneled in pairs anymore.  As long as there is appropriate visual
column2: auditory and olfactory contact with other dogs they may be kenneled in adjoining enclosures.

column1: Ban on all collars that inflict pain (Art. 73 abs. 2)
Because new types of collars have been developed to circumvent the ban on prong collars
column2: this loophole has been closed. All collars or 'guiding aids' which cause pain are forbidden
column3: and the use of choke collars without a stop is explicitly forbidden.

column1: Private Schutzhund training (Art. 74)
Previously Schutzhund training was allowed only for the army
column3: border guards and dogs competing in organized sport. The law did not address the training of dogs used by private security services
column4: now private Schutzhund training is included.

column1: Training hunting dogs with live animals (Art. 75)
Previously the use of live animals was only allowed in training 'ground hunting' (my note: 'Baujagd'
column2: I think this means scent hunters - anyone more familiar with the sport please correct me)
column3: in livestock guardian training
column4: and in herding dogs. Now it will be allowed in training wild boar hunting and in retrieving. Direct contact between the dog and animal used in training is forbidden - the only exception will be when it is essential to the training or testing of the dog. The wild animal must be allowed to retreat to cover. Training grounds where live wild animals are used are subject to approval of the cantonal authorities.

column1: Prohibition of devises that prevent noise or the expression of pain (Art. 76)
Devises designed to prevent an animal from making noise or expressing pain are forbidden
column2: with the exception of those attached to a collar that emit a blast of air or water. No other such devises
column3: such as those emitting an scented essence
column4: may be used.

column1: My note: Electric shock collars
column3: acoustic collars are still banned for the general public. The use by licensed professionals remains regulated by the canton.

column1: Animal shelters or animal care services such as dog sitters
column2: dog walkers or people who take in animals while owners are on holiday
column3: need a cantonal license as soon as they care for more than 5 animals. The carer's own animals are not counted in that number. Breeders and rescue organization selling/rehoming a large number of animals per year require a permit from the canton. (The exact numbers are stipulated in 101.c.1-7)   One will need the appropriate training course or diploma to be granted a permit as an animal carer. Pet owners are reminded to ask for the cantonal permit when you give your animal into the care of someone else.

column1: My note: For shelters or other commercial providers of animal care who care  for max 5 animals
column2: it is enough that the responsible person possesses 'the requisite training'. This is quite a change from current regs (for instance
column3: I'm assuming 'verlangte Ausbildung'  means the SKN for dog carers) and I would urge those of you offering/using pet care to clarify this with the BVet.

column1: There is also a revision to the articles governing keeping horses
column2: but since that is a specialist topic I'll leave those interested to read for themselves.

column1: Again - these changes are not set to go into effect until 1 Jan 2014.
Animal welfare legislation (at the federal level) and animal control legislation (at the cantonal level) are both subject to change. Pet owners and pet carers should keep this in mind.

column1: Roughly:
Leaving a dog all day long in a car (for instance
column2: during work hours) is not allowed.  Leaving a dog in a car is deemed to be the same as leaving him in a crate/box
column3: where the space does not meet the minimum legal size.

column1: Here is the law that ZÃ¼richtierschutz is referring to: Note that the federal animal welfare law does not directly ban leaving a dog in a car
column2: but rather sets out requirements for the minimum space a dog must have in any kind of kennel. ZÃ¼rich Tierschutz interprets the law on kenneling to apply given the length of time the dog is left in the car.

column1: See Art. 72. Boden
column3: Tabelle 10
column4: Haushunde (p.92.)

column1: OK - So what should be done?
First
column2: do you believe the dog to be in immediate mortal danger? Anytime there is a reasonable suspicion of immediate mortal danger one shoud act immediately - which means calling the police in the first instance
column3: or Tierschutz. But first one should take responsible steps to ascertain whether 'immediate mortal danger' applies or not.

column1: A car in a garage is usually not as dangerous as a car left outside
column2: but garages can still get too cold or too hot
column3: resulting in danger of heat stroke or freezing
column4: ventilation can be a problem even in safe temperatures. Leaving a dog in a car where the temperatures are too hot or cold and pose an immediate risk to the animal can be an act of 'Tierqualerei'
column5: which (depending on the details of the case
column6: of course) can be punishable under the animal welfare law.

column1: However - if the dog is not in immediate mortal danger
column2: it is best to take a more measured approach. Speak to the dog owner first
column3: explain your concerns.

column1: If the dog is indeed safe and seems happy in the car
column2: do not go to the authorities before talking to the owner.  Remember
column3: the goal is to help the dog and owner find a solution. Unless an animal is in immediate mortal danger
column4: one usually has a better chance of making a positive change if one approaches concerns as a friend ready to help rather than with condemnation.  For the sake of the animal
column5: again barring immediate mortal danger
column6: it is usually more effective to work with the dog owner than against him.

column1: Find out exactly how the car is set up.
(I know people who have gone to great lengths to design their cars boot space specially for their dogs
column3: sleeping and play areas
column4: some cars are roomy enough
column5: etc. Not every car is 'just a box'. But the issue of compliance with 455.1 still remains. If the car complies with 455.1
column6: if temperature/ventilation is deemed to be safe
column7: then under the law there is likely no grounds for action.)

column1: Find out the reason the dog owner is doing this. For instance
column2: it's not uncommon that landlords forbid tenants from leaving a dog unattended in a flat. The owner might not be allowed to leave the dog at home.

column1: Once you know the why
column2: once you have ascertained that leaving the dog in the car does not comply with 455.1
column3: then offer to help find a dog care solution that addresses that reason
column4: such as a Hort or other day care provider or a dog sitter who would stay in the flat. Do you know  of a good day care provider? Do you know of someone who could care for the dog in the owner's flat if a Hort is not appropriate for this dog? If you don't
column5: could you help your friend find someone?

column1: Focus on helping to find a solution. What you don't want to do is to invoke the law leaving the owner with no alternative
column2: possibly forcing him to give up the dog. That won't help the dog
column3: which is what this is all about. Yes
column4: 'Gesetz ist Gesetz'
column5: but the day to day reality of animal welfare work is all about protecting the animal first and foremost - which often means working quietly to help the owner rather than blazing in brandishing the law.

column1: Whenever one has concerns about a animal related situation
column2: once can always ask the relevant Tierschutz organization for advice
column3: or ask Tier Im Recht. Best to proceed from fact - and these are the folks who know the laws
column4: who can best advise re: practical solutions.

column1: Good for you for caring - and I hope a solution can be found. Paws crossed
