column1: 859	Pet corner	Any tips on keeping chickens?	Bobby.Buchi	6
Yes
column2: a certain amount of moping after a move is normal.  As long as they are still eating and drinking
column3: don't worry about it. They'll settle in in a few days.

column1: Did the coop come with the chickens?  If not
column2: keep them shut in it and don't let them out for at least three days - they need to learn where ""home"" is so that they find their way back to it when they do go out.

column1: How old are they - I'm assuming full grown?  Hens
They need water.  A plastic bucket is OK
column2: try to get one that's about chicken-head-height.  Won't hurt them if they have to stretch a little to get a drink
column3: and the taller and heavier it is the less likely they are to knock it over or scratch food and straw into it.  The water should be changed every day.  In winter you'll need to go down first thing in the morning and break the ice off it
column4: top it up with hot water.  I also used to feed them a hot breakfast on winter mornings (just their regular food with a bit of hot water poured over it
column5: like a sort of chicken porridge - they go nuts for it.)

column1: Food - I second the recommendation to get some more pellety stuff if you can.  Don't know what's available here though.  They also need some grit (e.g. ground oyster shells) or small stones like you'd put in an aquarium.  You can just scatter a couple handfuls of this around their yard
column2: they'll find it and pick it up as they need it.

column1: They will eat all sorts of kitchen scraps - well
column2: almost all sorts. Mine hated bananas.  They'd take an experimental peck and immediately start wiping their beaks on the side of my shoe(!) trying to get rid of the nasty stuff.  But potato peelings
column3: onion tops and tails
column4: anything like that... also meat scraps.  And they will   stale bread.  Feed it to them by hand and you've got a friend for life.

column1: If you have hens they need a place to lay their eggs.  A good nesting box should be big enough for the hen to turn around in but not much larger.  It should be up off the floor (maybe a foot off the floor) and open in front
column3: back and sides.  Put some straw or wood chips in it
column4: which they can then arrange to their satisfaction.  One nesting box is enough for four or five hens.  They'll probably find it and start using it on their own
column5: but if you do keep finding eggs in odd places
column6: pick them up and put them in the nesting box.  This time of year
column7: an extra day or two won't hurt them (eggs will keep at room temperature for several weeks) and the hens will start laying there once they see other eggs there.

column1: Oh
column2: and they need to be shut in at night - summer   winter - to keep them safe from foxes
column3: neighborhood cats
column4: etc.  They'll go in by themselves around dusk
column5: you just need to count heads and shut the door.  If one or two are hanging around outside you can gently chivvy them in.

column2: all my dogs were adopted as adults and regardless of their 'mother tongues' I teach them all commands in English

column4: hand signals.

column1: Learning the commands in the local language is really for the benefit of passers-by
column2: a bit of theater so that folks who are uneasy with dogs can see that mine are under control. But it's also useful
column3: as your dog sitter or vets might use the German.

column1: So commands I use regularly:
Fuss - general heel
Hand - heel at right
Rechts/Links - left
Bleib - stay
Warte - wait
Sitz - sit
Platz - down
Drehen - turn
Rund um - to go around
Ruhig - quiet
Kom! come
zu mir - to me
Front - front
column2: oddly my trainer uses this in English

column1: Voran - sendaway
Apport! - Fetch
PfÃ¶tli - give paw. I do not use the gib Fuss that your site suggests
column2: as it is too close to the heel command.

column1: Steh - stand. (I only use the English 'stand'
column2: as the German 'steh' sounds too much like the English 'stay'
column3: confusing to the dog)

column1: Stop! - stop
Peng!  - Bang
column2: play dead - as in roll over belly up. (A trick that can be very useful on the exam table)

column1: Lass - leave
Pfui! - the general Swiss-German 'stop that!' used in emergencies. A gentle 'Ah' is preferable for everyday correction.
Genug - that's enough.
Frei! - free
column2: as in the exercise is over.

column1: Oh
column2: and the JÃ¶Ã¶Ã¶Ã¶Ã¶Ã¶... fiiiiiiiiiiiiiiine HÃ¼ndli! which you will (hopefully) hear from pasers-by as your dogs are sitting pretty.

column1: For complicated commands I use the English. So for sit pretty I'd say just that.
I actually use hand signals far more than verbal commands
column2: as dogs are more attune to body language/visual than the verbal. And I had a deaf dog.   All the other dogs picked up on his 'canine sign language' very quickly - and hand signals are universal
column3: not dependent on local language skills.

column1: But at the end of the day
column2: none of this matters. Anything we humans say is a foreign language to our dogs
column3: the words have no inherent meaning to them. We simply teach our dogs to associate a set of sounds with a desired action. I know a trainer who uses vegetables and fruits. 'Broccoli!' means heel
column4: 'Tomato!' means sit
column5: etc.

According to the Susy Utzinger Foundation for Animal Protection no one can just go out and start killing cats at random. Here is an excerpt from their publication in English about killing animals as it is currently.
[QUOTE]-> Legal situation regarding the killing of unwanted young animals
In Switzerland
column2: killing young animals without the appropriate expertise is forbidden. Killing an animal without professional training is a criminal act since it is classified as cruelty to animals and can therefore be reported.

column1: Cruelty to animals (Art. 26 of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act in Switzerland)
In Switzerland
column2: it is forbidden to kill animals cruelly or out of malice. Doing so is classified as cruelty to animals according to article 26 of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals act and is punished by imprisonment of up to three years
column3: or by a fine
column4: which can amount to several thousand Swiss francs.

column1: â€ƒ
What does Â“killing an animal cruelly or out of maliceÂ” mean?
Killing an animal out of malice means killing without having any sensible reason
column3: thoughtlessness
column4: callousness or on a whim.

column1: Killing an animal cruelly means that death is agonizing for the animal
column2: and/or means killing it unprofessionally and without following the regulations of the animal statutory order. Generally speaking
column3: an animal is killed cruelly if it was not adequately anaesthetized before its death so that it had to suffer or endure pain and fear.

column1: Regulations of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act

Article 177 of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act lays down the rule that vertebrates can only be killed by people who have the necessary knowledge and competence. According to article 185 of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act
column2: animals must be anaesthetized professionally prior to their death
column3: thus ensuring that they die immediately and painlessly.

column1: Examples of killing cruelly:
Â• Drowning animals
column3: cats
column4: chickens (death is very slow and extremely    agonizing)

column1: Â• Intentionally running into or over animals
Â• Laying out poisoned bait
Â• Shooting without appropriate expertise
Â• Letting animals freeze to death
Â• Letting animals starve to death
Summary

The killing of animals must fulfil the requirements of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act. The killing of animals can only be carried out under certain circumstances and with the appropriate expertise. In particular
column2: the killing method has to ensure that the animal loses consciousness immediately and that death sets in quickly without the animal regaining consciousness. There are special regulations concerning how animals are to be restrained when they are killed. The killing must not cause stress
column3: fear or a defensive reaction.

column1: According to article 26 of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act
column2: killing animals without these demands being fulfilled is classified as cruelty to animals and is punishable by imprisonment or a fine. This applies to livestock as well as to cats
column3: dogs and rabbits. As a rule
column4: only vets have the necessary expertise for killing an animal.

column1: What to do if you learn about the killing of young animals?
- Address and inform the person about the new legal situation and the Animal Protection Act.
- Offer various solutions to the problem (practical and financial support for the neutering of mother animals
column2: support for finding respectable and animal-friendly placing for the young animals).

column1: - Organise cooperation with and support from an animal welfare organization.
- If the person concerned does not listen to reason and if the animal welfare organization is unsuccessful
column2: press criminal charges against the person for cruelty to animals.

column1: 1113	Pet corner	Dog course	Patagonia	1
Hi there!

We attend the   A-Z   & Umgebung which is located at the Wiese(on the road where the Zoll Otterbach is located-Freiburgerstrasse) with our two Dackels. There are a variety of class levels and dogs that attend. Most classes are on Saturdays between 11 am and 2 pm and last 45 min. There are 3-4 trainers that rotate so that you usually get a different trainer every week or 2 weeks
column2: which can be quite fun. They also do a nice mix of agility and obedience training
column3: so it usually isn't boring. This is important as our older dackel gets verbal when he gets too bored sitting around doing nothing when he could be running around and digging holes.

column1: It is also very inexpensive at 200 CHF per year (if you go religiously there are ~30 classes per year). All classes are in Swiss German
column2: but the trainers have been very good about speaking high German with me (if I am alone) or English if I'm very lost. They also allow my partner (Swiss) and I to train together
column3: which has been beneficial for both of us (though more so for my comprehension of Swiss German).

column1: The website ( .ch/) seems to currently be down
column2: but I will lay out the basic schedule:

column1: 11:00-Noon: Welpenspielstunde
noon-13:00: Beginners class (basically 4 months old and up
column2: new people for a few classes
column3: etc...)

column1: 13:00-14:00: Intermediate

We currently attend the Expert training with our almost 3 year old dachshund and Intermediate training with our almost 1 year old dachshund. The trainers recommended that we skip the beginner class with the little one due to the class size (they have had over 10 dogs there on average) and our current experience-since we train weekly with our dogs at this club and our breed club. The trainers are all very patient and know all the regulars by name. We have met quite a few people there and I would highly recommend checking it out.If you would decide to check it out
column2: I would recommend going to the Beginners class to start. Make sure to bring your pet's passport so they can check that he/she is up to date with shots and have fun!

column1: Currently the school is on winter break until the 23rd of Feb. and then there will be normal classes and clicker courses.
Hope that helps.

column1: Please understand that 'Hundehandel' is a very dirty word in Switzerland. Importing dogs into Switzerland with the intent to sell them on is looked on as very dodgy. The people who operate like that are usually battery farmers/puppy mills. NO serious ethical breeder would even consider operating in such a manner.
Yes
column2: knowledgeable dog owners here in Switzerland often go to breeders in other countries - not surprising given how few breeders there are in Switzerland. A knowledgeable dog owner then imports the dog they have chosen themselves
column3: under the private import regulations.  - and very much frowned upon. People here expect to go directly to the breeder.

column1: A knowledgeable dog owner gets to know the breeder and dam (and sire when possible) personally
column2: usually well in advance of the birth. A knowledgeable owner investigates the ethics of the breeder
column3: ensures that the breeder's early socialization program is up to snuff
column4: researches lines
column5: checks that the breeder is a duly accredited member of the relevant breed club and that the sire/dam are properly angekÃ¶rt
column6: that all relevant health and temperament tests have been done... in short
column7: knowledgeable dog owners do due diligence.

column1: And a serious
column2: an ethical breeder does the same (and more!) with all potential buyers. A good breeder checks out the buyer
column3: requires the buyers to visit them and the dogs
column4: often several times as the pup grows
column5: and checks references.

column1: Knowledgeable Swiss dog owners expect this - and welcome it as a sign of a good breeder.
As said
column2: the people who ship dogs here to be sold on are generally battery farmers
column3: selling sick
column4: poorly bred dogs often under false pretenses. The BVet regularly runs campaigns against this awful trade
column5: to warn naive buyers.

column1: All would-be dog owners are required to take the SKN theory course BEFORE acquiring a dog. How to buy a dog

column4: the evils of 'Hundehandel' are discussed in the course.

column1: 1220	Pet corner	VAUD tightens Dog Laws	Verbier	3
The problem starts and ends with irresponsible owners. These restrictions are simply band-aids
column2: doing nothing whatsoever to address the root cause - and a could possibly cause more problems in the end.

column1: A dog whose behavior warrants it should be kept on lead or muzzled. No argument from me there. However these laws will aversely affect hundreds or thousands of dogs whose behavior is perfect
column3: whose owners have continually work on training
column4: who take responsibility for their pet and respect others.

column1: A concern with a muzzling requirement for all dogs - those whose behavior does not merit it - is that you have cut off an important natural communication point. Dogs communicate with one another (and with us
column2: if we pay attention) via body language. There are a range of facial expressions called 'calming signals' (read Turid Rugaas
column3: please!) that dogs use to navigate encounters with other dogs. A muzzle restricts the dog's ability to 'speak' with his face (set of mouth
column4: set of eyes
column5: etc.) or block the other dog's ability to read his face. The result can be that dog A can't see that dog B is trying to say ""hey
column6: it's all good""  - and suddenly conflict errupts.

column1: (Geneva's general muzzling requirement was struck down by the courts - it will be interesting to see what happens with the Vaud law.)

Most responsible owner will decide to leash or muzzle their dogs without being told. There are already laws on the books - in every canton -  that could deal with the few irresponsible ones. If those existing laws were actually enforced there would be no need for this new legislation.
I see this in many Swiss rules and regs - a law is on the books but it is not enforced - and there is no mechanism of enforcement. So half the population ignore it. The problem isn't solved so new
column2: stricter laws are passed. For which there is no enforcement mechanism so half the population ignore it
column3: and the problem continues....

column1: By the way
column2: I wrote to the VD VeterinarÃ¤mt several weeks ago asking how 'large' is defined in this law
column3: but have received no answer. Could I ask someone whose French is better than mine to do the same?

column1: As for banning based on breed alone: Bad science. In most cases it's how a dog is raised
column2: trained and treated that counts. The majority of pitbulls are actually bred/raised to be quite friendly to people. Even the poor dogs who have been trained to the fighting ring have to be people friendly
column3: so that they can be handled when their adrenaline is up.  It should be understood that dog-dog aggression does not automatically translate to dog-people aggression
column4: as the behavior is motivated by different instincts.

column1: Remember - the owner in the Oberglatt incident was a known criminal. The dogs had been illegally imported into Switzerland. They were kept starving (thought to be training for dogfighting) and at the time of the tragedy had been left in the care of someone incompetent to handle them. You heard right - under the new-ish federal animal welfare law (TSchV)
column2: dog owners are indeed required to take courses. These are called the Sachkundenachweis (SKN)
column3: and there are two types of mandatory classes:

column1: First time dog owners - that is
column2: anyone who has not had a dog registered in his/her name in Switzerland* - are required to take a theory course BEFORE acquiring a dog. This course discusses the basics of dog care
column3: dog laws
column4: your responsibilities as a dog owner in Swiss society. It is designed to prepare you for sharing your life with a four-footed friend - and to get you to ask yourself if you are indeed  ready to make this commitment and to stick to it for the next 15 or so years. The theory course is usually done over 2-3 lessions.

column1: All dog owners
column3: must take the practical training course within the first 12 months of ownership with each and every dog acquired after 1 Sept 2008. This is a very basic training course
column4: really just brushes the surface. The course is usually done over 5 lessons.

column1: The price of the courses may vary a bit by trainer - but usually are in the neighborhood of CHF 150.
Only a trainer certified by one of the BVet recognized organizations may teach the SKN; to find a trainer near you
You can read more about the courses on the BVet website:
And the subject has been discussed at length here
So as you are doing your research
column2: if you are required to do so
column3: take the theory SKN now - it's a good introduction to dog ownership in Switzerland.

column1: All the best.

* Folks who have owned a dog - as in the legal owner - in Ausland but not in Switzerland should contact the cantonal VeterinÃ¤ramt with proof of previous ownership for a decision as to whether you need to take the theory course
But - even if you are not required
column2: I would strongly recommend doing so - society's expectations of a dog owner are rather different in Switzerland than in other countries
column3: and the SKN sets you on the right road.

column2: JBZ - and one of the exceptions to the rule.

column1: I see the fall-out from poorly planned puppy ownership all the time.
When a 6-12 month old dog is handed in to our rescue
column2: most of the time it is because the owners got a cute puppy without understanding the amount of work that means and were not able/willing to devote the time needed to teach him how to live in the human world.

column1: Without consistent-on-the-spot training
column3: and reinforcement that cute puppy can develop some annoying behaviors - and in some cases
column4: serious behavioral disorders.  And when that cute puppy turns into a rambunctious teenager - this is the point where the family dump the dog.

column1: Rehabilitation of a pup who did not receive adequate socilization during the critical fear periods can be very difficult.
Based on the intake interviews I've done in such cases
column2: the majority of those owners left the young puppy on his own for long stretches at a time
column3: and did not make adequate provisions for physical and mental stimulation
column4: socialization
column5: training. Surprise
column6: surprise - they now have an ASBO hound on their hands.

column1: Over the last 20 yearsI've spent too much time and shed too many tears picking up the pieces.
I firmly believe that one owes it to one's puppy to set him up for success from day one. That means being available - on the spot - whenever necessary in those early days
column2: to help him learn what he needs to know.

column1: Especially here in Switzerland
column2: where neighborhood intolerance of an imperfect dog often results in abandonment or a one-way trip to the vet.

column1: That said - I've told the story of Saint Swimbo's unexpected entry into my life before... (Post 15 here:   )
Yes
column2: it can be done. But it's bl**dy hard work - and owner and pup start out with one strike against them.

column1: It can work - IF the owner is creative
column2: IF the owner is willing/able to gather the resources necessary to provide for the pup
column3: IF the owner -   -  are willing to make the pup's welfare a number one priority. Some people can do this - but my rescue experience shows that many cannot. And the pup becomes a statistic.

column1: I've been there

column5: 16:22	"    This is just my -- one long-time owner's -- opinion. Other dog people on the forum may have other opinions.

column1: As an owner you're allowed to use some discretion with what you have done. Sure
column2: some things are required or highly recommended.

column1: Rabies vaccinations in Switzerland
column3: are a requirement anymore
column4: but rather are optional
column5: depending if/when/how much your dog travels abroad.

column1: Lepto is a vaccination that is only useful if you live in places where it is present. In the US
column3: DHLPP was a combo shot
column4: but now it's more commonly given as DHPP and the Lepto is optional because Lepto is so rare. I think here in CH they still push the DHLPP though.

column1: Rabies and DH(L)PP come in yearly vaccinations and tri-annual vaccinations. I like the tri-annual
column2: but if you're not staying put and your dog has to travel
column3: it's a waste on the rabies
column4: because you'll still have to have the annual vaccine for many situations
column5: even if the tri-annual is still valid.

column1: Bordatella is
column2: particularly if you have a social dog or frequently board your dog at a kennel. It's also not expensive.

column1: Lyme disease tests are a waste of money unless you're runing around in the forests or your dog is always outside. If you've never pulled a tick off of your dog
column2: Ã wouldn't bother with it. This is also a recent advent in veterinary care. I'd only started seeing this test pushed by vets in the past 3 years or so.

column1: Fecal float -- bah. I don't bother with this annually
column2: but I do get it periodically. Again
column3: if it's an indoor dog and they're not out eating shit (and I mean that literally) or garbage
column4: then the odds of getting worms are nil.

column1: Dewormer -- This stuff is poison
column2: and I won't allow it to go into my dog without a reason.  So it's gotta be a fecal float first or I have to have seen tapeworms in their stools.  I won't allow it ""just 'cause"".

column1: Heartworm test -- if you're routinely using prevention
column2: then the annual heartworm test is also something that you can have done at discretion. Also
column3: again
column4: use your judgement. What's the risk? were there a lot of mosquitos? do you live near a wetland? Is your dog an indoor dog or an outdoor dog? I get this one infrequently as well.

column1: DENTAL -- don't forget the dental!!! Taking care of Fido's teeth is very important
column2: because he's gotta keep those choppers for 10
column4: 15+ years! Be sure to discuss a professional cleaning with your vet
column5: if one is necessary.

column1: But when we switched to the ""perfect food""
column3: digestive problems
column4: constant diarrhea
column5: and allergies started (such as small pimples on skin and licking of paws). However
column6: with her experiencing her first spring (winter baby)

column8: the diarrhea was not good
column9: and I could she is visibly uncomfortable on this food. So it's out.

column1: I started feeding a homemade diet of rice and hamburger
column2: but always worry about the lack of vitamins with a really excellent supplement.

column1: So I slowly started to introduce ACANA. And unfortunately
column3: the same thing happened again. So I started feeding a homemade diet of rice and scrambled eggs
column4: with carrots and peas. I also adding a small amount of natural yogurt to settle her stomach and give her some digestive enzymes. And again she was fine.

column1: But yes
column2: what is good in my eyes may not meet the specific needs of my dog. My original need to switch was prompted by her eating dirt and leaves off the ground. Probably a puppy issue
column3: as my vet says

column1: And after all
column2: with these high protein diets meant to be closer to the ""natural"" diet
column3: I must also consider...now ""natural"" or ""wild"" is my 5 kg. Maltese. Probably not able to handle that diet
column4: though perhaps her ancestors where. If I gave her a raw bone
column5: she would probably just look at it with a confused expression.

column1: So
column2: this leads me to where we are today. It seems her best diet is boiled meat or scrambled eggs with a rice.

column1: So as some of you mentioned
column2: I started to listen to her...well...poop.   I decided to get a great food
column3: 100% made in Switzerland
column4: (so ingredients are highly controlled) with a similar breakdown to what her body likes the most. Plus the vitamins and enzymes preferably.

column1: So I am going with AllFarm's ""Swiss Natural - Professional Pet Food"". It seems all this food is made in Switzerland...and must be directly ordered from the company in Weiermatt. They make horse food
column2: and other professional dog food. The breakdown for their Junior food seems to be exactly what she does best on when I feed her a homemade diet.

column1: So

column2: both mental and physical - this must be taken into account.

column1: I am loathe to make blanket judgements about dogs in appartments
column2: as appartment life is the norm in Switzerland. If we only rehomed to folks in detached houses the PTS rate would be sky-high. Rather
column3: it is important to assess the dog's individual needs
column4: and determine how this particular family will meet all the dog's needs in light of their particular housing situation.

column1: Creative solutions can be found for many housing situations   the family make the dog's needs a priority - now
column3: absolute commitment
column4: and often additional resources
column5: including money. Additionally
column6: one must consider neighborhood norms
column7: and the particular neighborhood the family lives in.

column1: 1498	Pet corner	Bringing cats to Switzerland	kalexis	1
column3: 13:32	"    Having brought two cats over this past August ourselves
column4: I can tell you a little about our experience and answer your questions relative to this experience.

column1: We had to have our cats microchipped with a specific type of microchip compatible with the readers used in Europe. (Not all vets carry this microchip) After that microchipping
column2: the cats had to receive a rabies vaccination (even if they were previously vaccinated
column3: it had to be done   the microchipping.  The veterinarian had to perform a health examination and certify the cats' health
column4: vaccination
column5: and microchipping on   and EU/Swiss form
column6: as well as a USDA form (required by the US Domestic airlines).   The form then had to be notarized by a USDA official. (3-hour round-trip drive for us)  The examination and notarization could not be done more than 10 (or 14?) days prior to the trip
column7: for it to be valid.

column1: Additionally
column2: we had to contact our airline (Delta) to determine the fees and requirements for flying with the animals (we wanted to bring them on the plane with us) as each airline has similar (but different enough to require researching individually) requirements.  We then had to purchase two soft-sided animal carriers small enough to fit under the seats
column3: absorbent piddle pads (like the kind used for housebreaking- it is a long trip) for any 'accidents'
column4: some sort of sedative/relaxant to use on the flight (again
column5: a long flight
column6: and you don't want everyone hating you because your cat is mewling the whole flight)
column7: and pay an additional $100 per animal fee to the airline.  We also packed two small bowls
column8: one for food and the other for water
column9: as well as some food for their trip.  Also note that each animal carrier counts as a carry-on item.

column1: The day of the flight
column3: we had to remove the cats from their carriers
column4: take off their collars
column5: and carry them individually through the metal detectors.  Meanwhile their carriers were screened like any other baggage.  The flight itself was extremely stressful
column6: as we worried about everything from the cats disrupting the flight to possible adverse effects from the sedative we were using.

column1: Upon arrival in Zurich
column2: we had to declare the cats at customs
column3: where the official very quickly scanned our paperwork
column4: did not look at the cats
column5: stamped the paperwork
column6: and sent us on our way.  This was both relieving (for its simplicity and lack of fees- we had been told to expect to pay a duty) and frustrating (we had gone to a lot of effort to have the paperwork in order
column7: and   even examined the paperwork) for us.

column1: When we were searching for apartments
column2: we did have to disclose our pets
column3: and we found it was about 50/50 on which apartments allowed pets.  Several of the 'no-pet' apartments told us that this was put in place mainly for large dogs
column4: and indoor-only cats were okay.  Our landlord did ask us to sign some additional paperwork regarding our pets (regarding liability for injury/damages) and I believe we had to provide additional deposit as well.  Our neighbors have been accepting of our cats also
column5: but I have read/heard stories where this is not always the case.      Its not required that they see a vet in Switzerland.  Since you are only planning on staying for 5 months
column6: I would just note where a good vet is
column7: in case of emergency
column8: and plan on getting them checked right before returning.      See our experience above.  Only if they have not been vaccinated since their microchipping and/or only if their current vaccine is more than one year old.      We have not crossed that bridge yet
column9: but I would imagine they will require recertification before returning to the US.  And the return trip will be equally stressful and complicated as the inbound trip.

column1: IMO
column2: for 5 months this is a LOT of stress & trouble for both you and your pets.  As much as I understand the desire to keep your pets with you
column3: it might be much less stressful for yourself and your cats (as well as less expensive) if you let them 'visit' with a trusted family member while you are gone.

column1: If you do decide to bring them
column2: and your company is paying to ship your belongings to Switzerland
column3: we recommend you purchase anything pet-related for these 5 months in the US (this includes food
column4: litter
column5: scratching posts
column6: treats
column7: bedding
column8: and toys) as it will be vastly cheaper to do it this way and include them in your shipment if you have room.

How comfortable are you with the other owner and dog? If you were to be concerned that things were getting out of hand
column2: would you be able to intervene? Do you think the other owner generally have the same ideas/philospohy about dog training?

column1: The important thing is to have the interaction be successful. Riotous play that both dogs enjoy is the most wonderful thing. Riotous play where one dog gets bullied can be problematic. Rioutous play that turns into a fight can be disastrous. It really depends on how steady the other dog is
As with everthing canine - listen to your instincts. You know your dog best.
If you decide to do this
column2: I'd probably start out by first doing a bit of parallel walking with the other dog and owner.

column1: This is where you start out separated by whatever distance your's dog's 'no fly zone' is
column3: keeping that distance constant.

column1: Watch how the dogs react to one another. Are both dogs relaxed? Look at the set of the ears
column3: the posture of the tail
column4: the hard/softness of the eyes
column5: etc.  What kind of signals are the dogs offering  each other?

column1: If all looks relaxed and friendly
column2: slowly reduce the distance between you and the other dog/owner. Continue walking in parallel
column3: continue reducing the distance as long as everybody seems happy - until you are waking together side by side.

column1: If anyone looks uncomfortable
column2: stop and increase the distance back to the previous point. Never go beyond what your dogs define as their comfort zones.

column1: Assuming you two are in a safe place where other dogs are unlikely to intrude
column3: happily walking side by side
column4: assuming all is going well - then casually release the dogs from the lead. Say nothing. You and the other owner should keep in motion
column5: walking around the area
column6: not directing the interaction but keeping an eye out. The dogs may just sniff around
column7: perhaps ignore each other - that's OK. Let them decide how they want to play.

column1: Presenting a neutral facade
column2: watch the body language of the two dogs. If one starts to look uncomfortable
column3: or goes into defensive mode - keeping your voice neutral recall your dogs to you
column4: resume parallel walking.

column1: It's best to end on a successful note.
You may want to do this several times
column3: go at your dog's comfort pace. One eye on safety at all times.

column1: Enjoyable fun interaction with other dogs is fantastic
column2: dogs can learn so much from each other. BUT - in serious behavior cases
column3: this really isn't a subsitute for working with a pro. Adding the caveat that I don't know your dog
column4: can't see what is going on -  do search for a trainer who can observe and give you professional advice.

column1: My general rule of thumb is to be alert on off-leash walks and make sure that your dog is 100% reliable on recall. If you sense potential trouble
column3: leash him up till that ill behaving canine is out of the way. Thats the best we dog owners can do. If you arent comfortable with any dog approaching yours
column4: simply tell the owner no (usually in Switzerland
column5: dog owners are very respectful of other dogs on  leads and tend to call their canine to move on)
column6: or if the owner is too far away
column7: step in as the human (and the pack leader)
column8: and send the message to the other dog to move on. If your dog is what you've described as well behaved
column9: he/she will simply ignore and calmly move on. No harm done.

column3: etc

We brought our then 11 year old cat with us from the States just about three years ago. He handled the flight like a champ...came out from the bulk luggage pick-up in the Zurich Airport happy to see us
column2: but a little surprised at what he had just been through.

column1: We flew direct from Washington
column3: and didn't give the cat any tranquilizers
column4: as we had been advised by our vet against giving our cat tranquilizers
column5: because they wouldn't last the duration of the ~6 hour flight
column6: and that waking up in an airplane groggy from tranquilizers would be harder on him than experiencing the flight without tranquilizers.

column1: We did put our cat in cargo rather than carrying him onboard with us. He's a loud meow-er when it comes to travel
column2: and we figured that our fellow passengers and flight crew would not appreciate that for the flight.

column1: That's our story
1. Book a direct flight if it is at all possible. It is worth the extra money to avoid an extra flight leg and extra discomfort for the kitty. If you cannot fly direct
column2: do not fly through the U.K. (they have different and specific guidelines
column3: so it's best just to avoid that).

column1: 2. Verify the exact charges and specifications (including what types of carriers are allowed
column2: and what is allowed in the carrier) with the airline with which you want to fly. I believe that they can only accept a certain number of pets per flight
column3: so it's best to get your cats on the list earlier rather than later.

column1: 3. Share your flight details with your vet
column2: so she can advise you specifically with regards to what your cats would need for that sort of arrangement.

column1: If I can remember anything else from three years ago
I hope this helps. If you have any specific questions

column1: Every shelter has it's own policies
column2: put in place based on their experiences
column3: for the good of the animals in their care. Please don't write off adopting a rescue based on one experience.

column1: If one shelter is not a good match for you
column2: why not look farther? It's quite likely you will find a shelter with more flexible guidelines
column3: who would be happy to home to you.

column1: I would counsel you to take this shelter's objections to heart
column3: and think about how you might address the issue should it come up again. For instance
column4: think about how you would reassure a shelter about the safety measures you had in place for your old cat
column5: and what could you do to ensure the safety of another cat given the proximity to the road.

column1: Or taking another tack
column2: think about how you could show that the road is not the danger that the shelter assumes it is - for instance
column3: spend some time counting cars - what's the average traffic really like during the times your cat would be outside? As local vets or police how many accidents there have been in the last x years (a driver is supposed to report running over an animal).

column1: I know that it can be very demoralizing to be turned down when all you want to do is to do a good deed. But remember that the shelter staff don't know you - it's up to you to go the extra step show them that you are the best home possible for one of their charges. Think of it as you would a job interview - sometimes a well-thought out presentation is needed to sway the decision makers.
But if this one shelter is firm on their policies
column2: then do continue looking - other shelters may well have different views.

column2: fees vary depending on the services needed - but expect around CHF 25-50 per hour for a dog walker who comes round once a day. You may need to pay mileage on top of that.

column1: Daycare
column2: where you bring the dog to a carer's home or professional care facility
column3: can run from CHF 40-100+ per day. You would need to vet any facility carefully.

column1: In-home care
column2: where the sitter stays in the client's home
column3: generally starts at CHF 200 per day.

column1: Do be aware that professional (which in most cases means paid
column2: depending on how the business is set up) dog walkers and dog sitters are required to hold certain qualifications
column3: and be registered with the cantonal veterinary office.

column1: You are absolutely correct that there are dodgy sites out there. There are people offering dog sitting services who do not have the necessary qualifications/registration/insurance
column2: who are working 'schwarz'. A sitter/walker working illegally puts the client at risk.

column1: An alternative would be to find a friend with whom you can exchange dog care (as opposed to paying)  - but if this is a regular thing that goes on for more than 3 months that friend might need to do the SKN with your dog as well.
(Speaking of which
column2: don't forget that you must do the SKN theory course  you get a dog
column3: and then complete the practical course within the first 12 months.)

column1: Is the dog you are looking at a puppy
If a puppy
column2: you will need to have someone with him/her all day
column3: a dog walker who pops in for an hour is not enough.  A pup cannot be left for long
column4: this is a crucial socialization and training period. It would be grossly unfair to the pup - and you'd be setting yourself up for problems down the road. It is generally recommended that people who work full time should not get a puppy.

column1: An adult dog is a better choice for someone who is gone from the house full time - but you still need to choose the dog carefully. Some adult dogs could not handle being left while you work
column2: even with a dog walker - some would be fine. You'd need to understand the individual's character.

column1: All dogs need companionship
column3: and socialization - which requires quite a time-intensive commitment from you. When one works full time one often must devote pretty much all of one's free time to the dog
column4: in order to meet the dog's needs. But that's why we have dogs

column2: first can I say how wonderful that you have adopted an elderly dog in need - good for you!  There is something so very
column3: very special about the oldies
column4: they ask so little and have so much love to give. I wish you and Lady all the very best.

column1: Nutrition can be quite a complicated issue. Good nutrition is especially important with senior dogs as their appetites
column3: energy needs
column4: and emotional relationship with food changes as they age.

column1: Billhardie and FairyDust have given you very good advice.
My first thought when any of my mutts
column3: starts to get fussy with food is to look for an underlying physical problem. It is generally easier to address physical problems than psychological ones
column4: so I try to rule out physical causes first. Has Lady had a baseline blood chemistry done?  A blood chemistry is non-invasive and can give an idea of organ function so it's a good place to start. I do this as part of a regular senior dog check-up
column5: this is an easy way to catch some issues in a timely fashion.

column1: (Mine are generally hoovers-on-legs
column2: so turning up their noses at food starts my alarm bells ringing. An example: what I initially took as fussiness in my girl was acute pancreatitis
column3: fussiness in one of the boys turned out to be chronic IBD.)

column1: It is important that Lady gets a balanced
column2: nutritionally sound diet. That can be accomplished with either a good quality commercial diet
column3: or a vet-approved home made diet - but you want to ensure that Lady gets what she needs to eat
column4: not just what she wants to eat.

column1: The question is: Is Lady rejecting the foods you offer because she doesn't like the taste of that particular item
column2: because she is intolerant to an ingredient in the food
column3: or because she is holding out for something better (in her mind)?  If the first two
column4: the key is finding a nutritionally sound diet that Lady can and will eat. If the latter
column5: then some behavior work is needed.

column1: Some random thoughts:
In determining if a particular food suits Lady
column2: look first to her general energy levels - is she alert and age-appropriate energetic
column3: or lethargic? Also condition: how does her fur look - glossy
column4: or dry? And watch her stools.  Firm
column5: good color
column6: normal amount? (Ah
column7: the wonders of dog ownership - one quickly becomes something of a scatologist.) If her condition
column8: energy and stools are not so good
column9: she likely cannot tolerate one or more of the ingredients - which is why she may be rejecting the food.

column1: Allergies or intolerance to foods are not uncommon; you might start with something Lady has not had before
column2: perhaps a fish and potato based diet
column3: and see how that goes. Some dogs needs a grain-free diet
column4: some need different levels of protein. We feed Magnusson
column5: a baked kibble - most extruded kibbles are too greasy for my guys
column6: the baked food suits them better. Adding hot water to the kibble helps bring out the smell
column7: making the food a bit more appetizing. And mush is easier on my ancient almost toothless guy than kibble.  Lady might tolerate a senior diet better.

column1: If Lady absolutely cannot eat kibble
column2: then a home-made diet is a possibility. But here it is very important to get the nutrition right. Any home-made diet probably needs a vitamin and mineral supplement
column3: and you should ask your vet to analyze any home-made diet to ensure that it is indeed nutritionally sound.

column1: A very good resource discussing canine diets is the Whole Dog Journal. The magazine analyses commercial dry and wet foods
column2: as well as home made diets and raw feeding - lots of good articles. In light of the melamine scandal of a few years ago
column3: assessing quality and ethics of commercial companies has become a mission with them. This magazine is US based
column4: so some of the commercial diets discussed are not available here.

column1: The magazine is subscription only
column2: but there is limited free content on their website:

column1: There are times when I have fed home-made; the diet I followed is here:
But please note that supplements are required.
Changing foods can cause stomach upsets for some dogs; for this reason chopping-and-changing
column2: trying different foods often to find something Lady likes
column3: can be sort of self-defeating. As you look for a good food
column4: try to stick with one for a while so that you get an idea of what Lady tolerates.

column1: Assuming that Lady has been given a clean bill of health
column2: then there is likely a behavioral reason
column3: perhaps a relic of Lady's past. The bread and milk thing suggests that she has been fed this way in the past. (And no
column4: bread and mild not a sound diet. ) However
column5: if she was in a Tierheim for 8 months than surely she was fed on a no-nonsense kibble diet during that time. Have you spoken to the Tierheim to get an idea of her behavior around food there?

column1: If the food rejection is largely behavioral you need to decide what approach to take. With a healthy dog
column2: I'd probably take a pretty hard line.

column1: If she is in good health
column2: missing a meal or two won't hurt her - I'd try putting her food down
column3: give her the 'time to eat' command
column4: leave the bowl for ten minutes
column5: then take it up again if uneaten. Ignore begging and pleading looks until next mealtime. Most dogs catch on quickly that nothing else will be on offer
column6: so I'd best tuck in.

column1: When doing this it is important that you remain absolutely non-reactive. Meals should be a neutral time
column2: not a time when you get upset at her behavior
column3: or a time when you coax her to eat
column4: bringing emotion into the event. (I know this is difficult to do when one is worried about one's pet.)

column1: Please note - this only appropriate if Lady is in good health. - If she has any health concerns do not do this without first speaking to your vet.
Another approach might be to do away with meals altogether.  My two younger dogs don't get food in bowls - instead they get their daily ration one piece of kibble at a time
column2: as training rewards throughout the day. (This means I walk around with pockets full of kibble all day
column3: but hey ho...)

column1: Will Lady accept dry kibble from you
column2: as opposed to eating it in a bowl? Does she like to train? If so
column3: perhaps you could try this. My guys love to work
column4: love training. Feeding as rewards rather than meals has the added benefit of cementing the bond between us
column5: gives the dogs the brain training they so love - and keeps them from getting fat. If I fed meals in addition to training rewards mine would both be barrels.

column1: A variation on that is to turn mealtime into a game - this is good for play-oriented dogs. I have a treat dispenser that looks like a gumball machine with a lever. I trained my girl to press the lever to get a piece of kibble. Some days I put her part of her  food allowance in the dispenser - she loves the 'self-service' game. You can do the same with a treat ball or cube
column2: or home-made activity box. Another game is search: I hide kibble in toys
column3: containers
column4: etc around the room
column5: give my dog the 'search!' command -  she runs around the room looking for her food.  If Lady is play oriented
column6: doing something similar might be a way to motivate her to eat.

column1: Be aware
column3: that turning meals into a game can back fire with some dogs. Mealtime as playtime might not fit into your schedule every day.  The key is you decide when the game is played.

column1: You could also feed  Lady in a kong if she likes those - stuff a kong with either kibble mush or your home made diet.

Do you think Newton's behavior around food might influence Lady in any way? Could interaction between the two over food play a part in Lady's fussiness? I've seen some dogs reluctant to eat in the presence of others
column2: sometimes because of subtle signals the other dog gives off.  On the other hand
column3: I've seen some who get food-obsessive and bolt it down when other dogs are around. Something to think about.

column1: (I had accidental success curing my MILs fussy-eater cairn when she came to stay with me for a holiday
column2: simply by feeding her in the same room as my piglet of a collie. The cairn was doing her usual diva routine and before I could stop him
column3: my collie scarfed down all her food. The little cairn quickly became a paid up member of the clean plate club after that. Be careful though - you don't want to set up a food jealousy or resource guarding situation.)

column1: Another thought:  how much food Lady does actually need?  The feeding recommendations on many foods are notoriously over-generous. My healthy dogs get ca. 10g food per kg bodyweight - which works out to a little more than 1/2 the recommended allowance of many foods. If I fed mine the manufacturer's recommended amount
Also
column2: perhaps Lady needs small meals more often - my boy with IBD can only eat a spoonful or two at a time - so he eats 4-6  tiny meals a day. Many senior dogs have digestive issues; feeding little and often seems to help. If you find this is the case a vet visit is likely in order.

column1: These are just some random thoughts
column3: some not.  Start by checking for or ruling out any physical reason why Lady might not want to eat
column4: and then spend some time observing her behavior around food. Perhaps with more specifics we can come up with some more appropriate ideas.

column1: Good luck - and bon appetite!
ETA:  Re: adding bullion to Lady's food. While adding something appetizing is often a good idea
column2: I'd stay away from commercial bullion  because of the huge salt content - especially in a senior dog where kidney problems could be a risk. Rather
column3: make your own so that you get the meat smell and flavor but no salt.

column5: security demanded that we put the soft cage through the x-ray machine (although it was bought in the airport 10 minutes beforehand). We refused to put Shirley herself in the x-ray machine
column6: so they suggested that we take her to a quiet room nearby where I held her in my arms while the security guys scanned her cage.

column1: I don't want to imagine how she felt throughout this journey. But I'm happy to see that less than 24 hours have passed since our arrival and she is already getting used to her new home (spent the night in our bed; walking on my keyboard while I'm trying to write this post :-)

column1: 1933	Pet corner	true nature of a dog	Araviind	2
Here's a little more to the story (and don't worry
column2: no dogs were harmed). This took place in early June of 1991. After the fighting was over in Kuwait
column3: my unit had to wait it's turn to fly back to the United States. Because we were one of the last units to arrive (Christmas day
column4: 1990) we wound up sitting in the desert outside the city of Al Jahra. By June
column5: the area was declared safe and Kuwaiti citizens were just starting to return to the area.

column1: With absolutely nothing to do besides wait
column2: we took to getting ourselves back into good physical condition. My buddy Tom and I decided to go for a 3 mile run
column3: and because it was extremely hot and the fighting was over for months
column4: we decided to not bring our rifles with us. When we were about a mile out of our camp
column5: I saw the dog pack. Being a dog lover
column6: I thought ""Oh how cute. a bunch of puppies!"". The dogs looked at us and thought ""Oh how cute. Lunch has arrived"".

column1: The dogs ran towards us and it didn't take long to figure out that they were not looking to have their ears scratched or bellies rubbed. They quickly surrounded us and began their attempts to separate us. We stood back to back and started looking for some kind of weapon for protection. When we tried kicking or punching
column2: the dogs snapped at us. Although they were not big
column3: they made up for it with speed. If a dog doesn't want you to touch him
column4: they can easily jump out of the way and take a bite out of your hand.

column1: We were in open desert with absolutely nothing around us. We kicked in the sand for rocks and the best we could come up with were small pebbles. Nothing that could hurt a dog
column2: but they didn't know that. Luckily
column3: the dogs had had a few rocks thrown at them before
column4: so they would back off if you looked as though you might throw one. Actually throwing the pebble was a mistake because they knew we were then defenseless.

column1: So we held our pebbles above our heads and started our way back towards base camp. We had to move slowly or the dogs would lunge at us more boldly. We also had to constantly turn in a circle. If we ignored any angle for too long
column2: the dogs covering that area would move in on us. After about 30 minutes
column3: which felt like hours under the hot sun and the bad situation
column4: a Humvee (American military vehicle) saw us and drove up. The driver got out and fired a few shots into the air. The dogs took off running farther into the desert. The driver got back into his Humvee without so much as saying hello and drove off (a ride back to our base camp would have been the polite thing to offer). Tom and I sprinted the remaining half mile back to base camp where we took our fair share of ribbing for being scared of a bunch of mutts. We never left base camp again without our rifles or in large groups.

column1: The fact that these dogs could survive out there was absolutely amazing. I have no idea how they were staying hydrated
column2: and what they were eating for food was a pretty grim prospect. I remember a few of the dogs looking as though they were apologetic or unsure if they were doing the right thing. Others looked quite savage as though they never knew about the traditional bond between man and dog. We were just prey to them. The alpha dog of the pack had a real intelligence to his eyes. He looked like a smaller version of an Australian Dingo and was maybe 15 kilograms. From time to time some of the dogs would start backing away like they had doubts about the venture
column3: and the alpha would then bark at us even more fiercely
column4: which would rally the other dogs back into the hunt. We focused our threats of thrown pebbles towards him because all of the other dogs would jump back when he jumped back
column5: and when he moved forward
column6: they all joined in.

column1: Looking back on this it seems very interesting. At the time I was genuinely in fear for my life. They may not have been big
column2: but with so many attacking at once
column3: I am quite sure they could have killed us.

column1: Tierheim PfÃ¶tli has a good reputation.
A list of Tierheime in other cantons can also be found on the Tierschutz site. Don't let geography be a deciding factor; Switzerland is a small place
column2: and traveling the length and breadth of the country to adopt a dog who tugs at one's heartstrings is frequently done.

column1: Be aware that some shelters require a handover fee
column2: to aid in the (sometimes significant) costs the rescue incurs in taking care of your pet.

column1: (Volunteer hat on...)
Is there really no way that you can keep your dog?
(You don't need to answer that here -  but I hope that you have looked into all possibilities to try to keep him. After all
column2: when we take on a pet it is with the understanding that we have made a life-long commitment.)

column1: If you   give up your pet
column2: please do all that you can to help him find a good forever home. It will take work on your part to find a good Tierheim
column3: and there is a chance that it may take time before a rescue place is available. .

column1: Giving the rescue as much information as possible about your dog's good -  and perhaps difficult - points is important. Absolute honesty will help your dog find the right people this time around.
And please if you are giving the dog up through no fault of his own
column2: make that very clear to the rescue. Again
column3: this will help considerably to finding him a new home.

column1: Give the rescue as much information as possible about his health
column2: give them copies of his vaccination records
column3: a summary of the training he has had to date - as well as the training that is missing. Can he live with children
column4: and if so
column5: what ages? Can he live with other dogs? If so
column6: are there any concerns over living with a dog of the same sex? Can he live with cats? Can he live with small furries? Can he live with livestock?

column1: If he/she is not yet spayed/neutered please have that done before you give your dog up - it will save the rescue much needed funds
column2: and is the right thing to do.

column1: Wishing your dog all the best - may he soon find a family who will truly commit to giving him the forever home he deserves.

column1: I will always advise those looking for a canine companion to consider rescue first - so many wonderful dogs looking for homes
column2: the need is so great. Most dogs end up in rescue through no fault of their own. You will find all manner of dogs in rescue
column3: from puppies to (already trained   ) adults to seniors - from pure breeds to delightful one of a kind mixes. All my guys are rescues - and I thank doG every day that I have been given the privilege of sharing my life with them.

column1: However
column2: if you feel that rescue is not the route for you
column3: then please only go to a reputable breeder. NEVER buy a dog from a pet shop - chances are those poor puppies on display in a shop window
column4: - deprived of the opportunities for socialization and learning so critical at that age - came from a puppy mill (or the more accurate
column5: less fluffeh term: battery farmed dogs   ). No breeder of any worth or ethics would ever consider allowing a puppy to be sold via a pet store.

column1: (In fact I don't think it's even legal to sell puppies in pet stores in Switzerland... someone please correct me if I'm wrong.)
A good breeder will not sell you a puppy via the internet shipped to your door
column2: nor will a good breeder meet you at some highway rest stop to dump off a puppy. Again
column3: these are all signs of dodgy battery farmers.

column1: Dodgy breeders - whether battery farmers or clueless BYBs - don't do health or temperament checks of the parents
column2: such folk care little for the genetic health of the line - meaning the cute puppy you buy may be seriously ill. Battery farmers often breed in appallingly cruel conditions - the dogs are treated as little more than machines
column3: and dumped or killed once no longer profitable.  It is filthy
column4: vile trade - please do not support it.

column1: A good breeder will require you to meet him far in advance of bringing a pup home - many even have waiting lists well in advance of conception. A good breeder will grill you carefully to determine if you can indeed provide a good home for one of his dogs. (A good rescue will make you jump through the same hoops.) A good breeder only breeds dogs who are genetically and temperamentally healthy
column2: socializes the pups in a nurturing environment - giving your puppy the best start in life.

column1: The BVet has a good brochure on the subject: ""Augen Auf beim Hundekauf"".
To find a reputable breeder
column2: see the SKG (the Swiss Kennel Club) website

column1: But even before you take that step
column2: please research the different dog breeds. Think about breed characteristics
column3: and think hard about your lifestyle and what you can offer the dog. Look for a breed whose needs match your lifestyle.

column1: And then - under the new Animal Welfare Law
column2: if you are a first time owner you will need to take the theory class of the Sachkundenachweis   you purchase your pup.

column1: 2247	Pet corner	getting a second cat	guest	993	3	null	1.1.0001
I have plenty of experience with this situation
column2: as all my life we have added kittens to my home. And you are right
column3: your cat is probably very lonely being alone during the day
column4: and I did the same thing for my cat about two years ago. I didn't necessarily want another cat but knew it was better for my love (who was definitely lonely).

column1: A few simple guidelines
column2: and there should be no problem with the integration.

column1: 1. It doesn't matter the sex of the first cat or the second for that matter. I prefer males
column2: so I never get a female (and have never had a problem). What matters is the AGE of the cat. If you want things to really go off without a hitch
column3: you have to get a kitten and preferably a young one at that (no older than 12 weeks in my opinion). There is a dominance issue that has to be worked out naturally; so for your cat
column4: he considers your house to be his territory and he thus has to feel like he is in control of the situation (even though he really isn't) when a stranger (ie-the kitten) arrives. So make sure to let this play out. There will be hissing and growling
column5: but it will work itself out for sure.

column1: 2. If/when you get the kitten
column2: make sure to keep them separated from each other for at least a week. Normally
column3: I acclimate the kitten in the bathroom b/c it is the perfect location for controlling messes while litter training as well. You can do occasional 'supervised' visits where you introduce them to each other with you around
column4: and as time goes by (and dependent on your cat's reaction)
column5: you can make these more frequent until separation is no longer necessary.

column1: The only other thing I can say is to make sure that the new kitten has a clean bill of heath from the vet just so that no diseases are spread. This can be a problem.
Otherwise
column2: I hope you enjoy your new kitten (and your cat does too)!

Not knowing all the relevant details I'm hesitant to second-guess your vet... But as a general rule:
If you are uneasy with the approach your vet has taken
column2: speak to her - ask her why A and not B. She should have given you a full explanation and discussed the whys and wherefores of her treatment plan with you before proceeding.

column1: There can be many ways to treat a given condition - one is not necessarily right and the other wrong - rather
column2: the question is often what is most appropriate for an individual in a given situation. I expect my vet to discuss available options and outcomes
column3: and together we decide which approach is best for my mutt.

column1: I firmly believe that an owner has to be respected as an equal partner in all decisions concerning the treatment of our animals. (It took me a couple of tries before finding a vet whose ideas meshed with my own.   )

I've run into a few vets (and doctors   ) who've shown a somewhat patronizing attitude towards owners/patients - who perhaps don't give the layman credit for the general knowledge that comes with being an experienced owner. Or perhaps some owners in your vet's practice may not feel comfortable doing their own first aid or after care
column2: hence the request to have you bring your dog in so often?  But - again bearing in mind that I don't know the details of your dog's condition and so can only speak in generalities -  I'd ask point-blank why the vet feels the need for follow up visits so often.  If an owner feels competent to do the after care
column3: my vet often prefers him or her to do so
column4: as the animal is far less stressed at home. And keeping the stress levels down aids recovery.

column1: Hopefully your vet will address your concerns to your satisfaction.
Oldhand has hit the nail on the head - listen to your gut instinct. Both in treating your dog now
column2: and in assessing any owner/vet relationship.

column1: As an Auslander
column2: I've claimed Heimatrecht and set up a trust in my will that ensures my dogs are provided for financially for the rest of their lives - the balance then goes to the rescue group who will care for them. But if I understand it correctly

column4: and some of the folks who would be obligatory heirs get zip) is not allowed.

column1: The family members who would be obligatory heirs under Swiss law are not really animal lovers; it worries me greatly that my taking Swiss citizenship could mean that the mutts would essentially be left to their goodwill. Volunteering with a rescue

column1: So a question for pet-owning Swiss citizens: How do you ensure your animals are provided for after your death
column2: given the restrictions of Swiss inheritance law?

2403	Pet corner	Is there a market for home-visit pet care?	Neil600	1
Neil
There are a lot of people offering casual pet sitting services - some good
column2: some not. Demand is very high during the school holidays
column3: so I would think that there is opportunity for you. If that is the kind of service you are considering offering
column4: think about what you can do to stand out from the crowd.

column1: In contrast
column2: there are very few people offering professional in-home sitting
column3: as the person I finally found does. As she is fully booked months in advance
column4: I assume that there is indeed demand for more of this kind of service.

column1: If you study the Animal Protection Law of 1 Sept 2008
column2: and if you keep your eyes on the proceedings going on in the WBK and their proposal working it's way through the federal legislative process
column3: you'll see that being the person in charge of a dog has become rather complex.  (Offering cat care services is far less complex
column4: as I understand it - but I am not a cat owner
column5: so am probably not au fait... ) Speak to the Bvet
column6: speak to an insurer
column7: speak to the Gemeinde and cantonal tax authorities about requirements.

column1: A few random thoughts and rhetorical questions
column2: from my perspective as a customer (dog owner):

column1: First
column2: think about how you will structure the business. For my part
column3: I want the sitter to be legally self employed. I wish to be a customer
column4: not an employer - and do not want to be put in a position where I could be construed to be an employer with an employer's liabilities. If a sitter is working illegally he/she could be putting the customer at risk
column5: in addition to running afoul of employent law one's self.

column1: In addition to properly registering with the tax authorities
column2: some dog sitters need to comply with Bvet regulations under the new Tierschutzgesetz. The owner's insurer might refuse to cover damages if the sitter is not fully compliant
column3: leaving the customer very much in the lurch.  (Think of the recent incident in Schaffhausen...)

column1: Pet sitting is not a casual job - it's a big responsibility. If I have booked the sitter
column2: I expect the sitter to fulfill that commitment. Most customers cannot easily change plans
column3: re-schedule flights
column4: etc - which means a sitter should have back-up
column5: in agreement with the client
column6: in case of emergencies on his/her part.

column1: As mentioned
column2: I use an in-home service - my sitter moves into my home in my absence
column3: living there 24/7 to care for my dogs. During the time I've booked
column4: caring for my mutts is not something the sitter does for a few hours on the side - it's a full time job. Even if you take the pet into your home
column5: the commitment is the same - would your family be able to cope with that? Do you have children or pets of your own? If so
column6: how would the business impact them - and would your children/ own pets/ home commitments limit the kind the pets you could care for?

column1: I expect demonstrable experience or qualifications. I need a sitter who is conversant in behavioral theory
column2: whose philosophy and methods mesh with mine. I would quiz a sitter thoroughly on how he/she would handle a variety of situations
column3: and I would set up a test period to evaluate the sitter's skills. Think about how you could convince a prospective customer that you are the right person to care for his/her pets. And
column4: what would you do if a customer's ideas differed from yours - think about who you want your customers to be.

column1: I expect a sitter to be fully conversant in local
column2: cantonal and federal animal welfare and control laws. And of course
column3: I expect a sitter to comply with those laws. For instance
column4: I see you are in canton ZH - be aware that new dog control legislation is in the pipeline following the cantonal vote last November.

column1: I expect a sitter to be able to deal with veterinary emergencies - which means knowing basic first aid
column2: having a good enough command of the local language to get through the answering service gatekeepers to get the dogs timely veterinary care or to speak to the clinic staff
column3: and having a car to transport the animal to the emergency clinic if needed.  A sitter needs to draw up a detailed agreement with the client as to how emergencies are handled.

column1: Are you willing/able/qualified to deal with special medical needs
column3: handling pets with limited mobility
column4: diabetes
column5: epilepsy
column6: etc? Could you care for an incontinent pet? Could you handle pets with behavioral challenges? And if so
column7: think about the liability issues surrounding taking on such responsibilities.

column1: If you choose to take pets into your home rather than watching them in the customer's home
column2: do you have permission from the landlord to do so if you rent? Do you have permission from the neighbors if necessary? Think about noise and neighborhood tolerance levels.

column1: And if you take pets into your home
column2: is your home safe for animals? Stairs? Hazzards? Is your garden securely fenced in? These are issues to discuss with your insurer.

column1: I am admittedly a demanding customer
column2: as I have dogs who are a bit of a challenge. My sitter offers me peace of mind
column3: knowing my mutts are in safe hands. For that I - and many dog owner in similar situations - are willing to pay a small fortune.

column1: The right  person
column3: can indeed do well with this gig.

column1: Wishing you well as you explore this venture...

Hi abzurich
I'd keep a close eye on him until you can get it checked out.

If it's asthma then the breathing can go into spasm which would need  medical attention because it can deteriorate. If you find he's having to keep his mouth open with tongue out then get him in quick.
MY cat had asthma and a number of treatments were tried as suggested by our vet:
1. asthma inhaler as used by babies - absolute waste of time an money and distressing for the cat
2. pills to be taken daily - did not work
3. steroid injection - once every 6-8 weeks
The injections worked best
column2: but was told they may have side affects - she was alot happier on those than the other treatments.

column1: Still a happy cat
column2: but sadly in the uk while i'm here ......meow

column1: My Hooligan is an ultra high energy dog - in hindsight
column2: one of the mistakes I made in the beginning was focusing on physical exercise to calm her down. She is extremely fit and can go all day long - but we reached a point where her stamina was such that she needed ever increasing amounts of exercise
column3: she became almost an adrenaline junkie. I could not tire her out physically; I don't live on a farm where she could run free all day
column4: nor do I have a herd of sheep for her to control. I soon realized I needed other ways to engage and stimulate her: brain-training does just that.

column1: I've found that interactive games where my dogs and I work together to be the most fun
column2: and are best mental work out for my guys. Most of the things we do are simple games easily incorporated into my daily household routine.

column1: I use a lot of clicker training - which is really just form of operant conditioning. First
column2: here is a good site explaining the basics:

column1: I use this method to teach my dogs something new
column2: something they might not instinctively understand. And then I try to turn training into a game.

column1: For instance
column2: my house often ends up littered with dog toys; you can't move without stepping on a squeeky. So when it's time to clean up
column3: I call the the dogs in to play the pick-up game. On my command
column4: the dogs search the room for toys - when one of my guys finds one
column5: he/she picks it up and puts it into the toy box - and gets a reward. On to the next toy... and the next...

column1: I do the same when gardening - the dogs bring me my gloves
column3: put the plastic pots in a pile for recycling
column4: etc.

column1: My friend taught her amazing lab to sort laundry using clicker training. I haven't gone that far
column2: as I expect my opportunistic sock thief would have a field day - and we would end up barefoot.

column1: You can use the basic idea to teach your dog anything - the point is to involve your dog in your mundane household activities. Ask yourself
column2: what part of this task could my dog do? Turn a chore into a game - the dog loves being with you
column3: figuring out what you want and how to do it
column4: getting praise from you. The dog enjoys the game
column5: and the activity reinforces your bond - and the mental exercise really does tire the dog out.

column1: There are lots of videos on YouTube demonstrating clicker basics
column2: as well as how to teach games/tricks.

column1: Teaching 'search' has been very handy - I can use this in so many ways
column2: from traditional dog activities like scenting a course
column3: to playing 'find it' games around the house.

column1: We also play with puzzle toys
column2: where the dog has to figure out how to make something work in order to get a reward. Nina Ottoson makes a fantastic line of dog toys
column3: really brilliant stuff
column4: top quality - and very expensive. As an easier-on-the-budget alternative
column5: I make most of our toys. My husband is into woodworking
column6: so he has done some variations on the Dogbrick - but most of our toys are made of cardboard boxes
column7: plastic bottles
column8: packaging materials - things you have lying around the house. I really like the Spass Mit Hund website - it's packed with great ideas:

column1: The authors have also written a book
column2: available in English translation ""Playtime For Your Dog'.

column1: Targeting games are another good mental work out - I use targeting a lot with my deaf dog who needs visual rather than auditory (clicker) cues. One game he loves: I give him an array of cards
column3: some square
column4: some star shaped
column5: etc. He has to touch each one differently - star with right paw
column6: round with nose
column7: square with left paw
column8: etc. I'm working on doing this with color variations as well. Targeting can be used for practical applications - a high five and 'gib pfotli' games
column9: for example
column10: are how I desensitized him to give me his paw so I can clip his nails.

column1: You can also make basic obedience training into a game around the house. My dogs tend to follow me around - usually underfoot
column2: tripping me up.   So taking that natural instinct
column3: I've taught them to off-lead heel - up the stairs
column4: into the kitchen
column5: through doorways
column6: etc. My morning coffee break is a good opportunity to teach a down-stay; our goal is to be able to hold a down for the time it takes me to finish my cuppa.

column1: Team Training teaches the dog a sequence of steps - turns
column3: etc.
column4: kind of like dog dancing.  The point is that the dog learns to focus on me while doing something that requires concentration. Now
column5: I have no interest in turning my dog into a circus performer - but it's a fun way to teach close-in work. A bit of serendipity - I've found this a very useful distraction/re-focus technique with my reactive dog.

column1: Yes
column2: my young to middle aged dogs do need a lot of physical exercise - they are herding dogs after all. But I've found that their brains need as much - if not more - exercise as their bodies do - it's all about balance. We play brain-training type games randomly throughout the day
column3: for short periods - a few minutes at a time really is enough. After a good mental work out
column4: my guys usually toddle off to their beds for a nice long nap.  And peace reigns throughout the house.

column1: I'd encourage you to find a training class or group you could join regularly for socialization as much as for training. The group I go to not only gives me support and encouragement
column3: but through the group the dogs and I have found some good friends.

column1: All the best to you and your dog.

column1: 2506	Pet corner	Importing Dog from USA	new2luzern	3
Now granted I'm not sure how much of this is taken care of by the animal shippers but the official rules we were given last year for bringing a dog here  in order to skip quarantine were:
First the dog has to have a microchip that is readable by European scanners - the typical US microchips are on a different frequency so you need to go somewhere like Petsmart which will put both in.

Rabies Vaccine less then 1 year old - and the vaccine has to be verified by:      (its the only lab in the US that does this - your local US vet will draw the samples and send it to them - I think it took us something like 6 weeks to get the results back)
Then you have to have a vet fill out papers
column2: followed by your state's USDA vet signing off and stamping that everything is in order and meets export rules.

column1: Then your dog will get to Switzerland and no one will even bother looking at all the papers you absolutely HAD to have to bring the dog here (but of course you have to have them if you actually do get asked).  I think that was everything anyway.  Good luck   "	28	 Jan 2007	1.0	['0'
