What we did do - that other people in a similar situation might find helpful - is borrow a digital scanner to take with us.  The bvet website states non-standard chips are okay if you carry your own scanner.

There is an organization called Digital Angel that will ship you a scanner free of charge anywhere in the US that you can take with you when you travel.  I just called them and they got it to me within a few days. (800) 328-0118.  You just have to mail the scanner back to them within 30 days.  They take a credit card number in case you don't return it.
After all that
column2: no one at the airport (on either end) ever asked for any documentation for the cats (we travelled with them in cabin).  Better safe than sorry though.

2590	Pet corner	Dog walking areas in Zug	8feet4paws	2

I moved to Walchwil (in Canton Zug) in August 2007 and am delighted at the number of amazing walks in and around the area which are dog friendly. All the walks seem to have doggy bins available and I often come accross other dogs which are being walked off leash. As people have mentioned before one has to be a responsible dog owner as farmers do not take kindly to there livestock being harrassed and in hunting season I tend to stay away from the woods (in Zug I believe hunting days are Monday Wednesday and Saturday). I have a very energetic weimeraner and she loves it here - we walk extensively in the Zugerberg and there are many quieter routes you can find when there are lots of people around. I invariably walk on my own on some very remote paths and always feel safe. The Swiss are generally very friendly and I make sure that if someone is walking without a dog I call mine back so she doesn't bother people who may not like dogs. There are also many beautiful walks that you can drive to - I often go to the Hunenburg river which is a very popular dog walking spot. There really are loads of appropriate places to let you dog off the leash and have a great time - I love it here.  "	5	 Mar 2008	0.0	['0'

2622	Pet corner	Relocating with our dogs	Tanya	1
At present
column2: dog laws vary by canton -The proposed federal law has not yet been passed. Whether it will be enacted in the future
column3: or what the final form will be
column4: is anyone's guess.

column1: Where are you moving to? For info on each canton's current regulations
In any case
column2: I believe your Bostons should have no problems. It's the poor 'bull' terriers who have been (unfairly   ) singled out.

column1: One thing you should consider - have your dogs flown before? Some airlines have special conditions for flying the brachycephalic breeds - you'll want to look into that.
As for how easy it is to rent... kind of a roll of the dice.    As your dogs are small you are in an easier position than we were. Are you under much of a time constraint with the move?
With our mutts
column2: temporary housing was not really viable
column3: so I made a trip over to find the house first. The house I chose wasn't going to be ready for another 3 months
column4: so the dogs and I stayed in the US for that time
column5: husband moved into a short term serviced appartment
column6: and we joined him in CH once we had the keys to the house.

column1: When I was house hunting I was told housing would be a huge problem
column2: but  in hindsight I have come to believe that was simply the relocation agent trying to scare us and squeeze a higher rent/commission out of us. (So stay away from the evil corporate relocation people!    )  Just stress to any potential landlord how well behaved and friendly and quiet your dogs are.

column1: (You may have to pay a higher deposit - we did - but again
column2: I think that was just our slimeball agent. Our Swiss neighbors
column3: who had dogs and rented from the same landlord
column4: did not have to put down more than the usual deposit.)

column1: We settled for an old home in a town outside the city
column2: with a large private garden. The house was small
column3: nothing special
column4: rather run-down
column5: and far too expensive for what it was. But it had adequate secure space for the dogs to run and play
column6: located in a dog-friendly neighborhood
column7: with lots of great walks in the area - which was all I really cared about.

column1: Make sure you have express permission to keep all four of your dogs written into  the lease - this is very important. And
column2: if there is anything else you need to arrange with the landlord - fencing
column3: etc.
column4: make sure you have an agreement in writing.

column1: You will want to consider taking out insurance against any damage the dogs might do to the rental property - as we found out to our cost
column2: this was NOT included in the standard    (private liability) insurance package offered by Winterthur.  We should have taken out a separate damage policy for that.  So make sure your insurer understands your needs.

column1: (And
column2: stay away from the awful Swiss parquet flooring if you can! Doesn't stand up to the pitter-patter of canine feet
column3: and is very expensive to replace if your landlord insists on it.)

column1: Good luck with your move.
